sentence: Exit with error code after gzip file read fail or throw "ERROR: sequence and quality have different length:". Add reads buffer size parameter.; #333 . I managed to complete it by myself. Please review it. And I found it will core dump or segment fault if not exit after gzip file read fail or after throw "ERROR: sequence and quality have different length:" error. Exit with error code (-1) will walk around of these kind of core dump.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Remove the use of getBytes (seekg)?; In order to replace the slow inbuilt gzip lib, we'd like to use pigz. However, the following command failed:. ```. fastp -i <(gzip -dc input_1.fq.gz) -I <(gzip -dc input_2.fq.gz) -o ...... . ```. after some investigation, I guess the issue is coming from getBytes(), because fseek is not supported by stream. . code: https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/blob/424900e376a02033a32b623bc5c836897f6b7e5a/src/fastqreader.cpp#L68. Is it possible to remove the use of fseek so we can pipe the stream to fastp? Or any other suggestions on how to use pigz with fastp? (without creating temporary files)
author: OpenGene

sentence: Inconsistency of insert size and total reads; Hi Thank you so much for developing FastP. In the output json file, e.g. http://opengene.org/fastp/fastp.json, the number of insert size (including unknown and the histogram) is a small fraction of the total_reads. Does FastP subsample total_reads for insert size analysis? Thanks!
author: OpenGene

sentence: Feature Request Split by Flowcell and Lane; I have whole genome sequencing and some FASTQ files consist of multiple runs, each done in a different lane and flow cell. It would be desirable if the software could split files more than by the number of reads or limiting file number.

sentence: Not global-trimming both front and tail simultaneously; I am using Fastp version 0.21.0. In my environment (Linux Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS), Fastp seems to fail to perform global-trimming for front and tail bases simultaneously. The command line `fastp –-in1 fq1.fq.gz –in2 fq2.fq.gz -f 8 -F 8 -t 8 -T 8` seems to perform global-trimming for only front 8bp sequences. Both ` fastp –-in1 fq1.fq.gz –in2 fq2.fq.gz -f 8 -F 8` and `fastp –-in1 fq1.fq.gz –in2 fq2.fq.gz -t 8 -T 8` worked well. Thus, `fastp --in1 fq1.fq.gz --in2 fq2.fq.gz --stdout -f 8 -F 8 | fastp --stdin --interleaved_in -t 8 -T 8` also worked well. If these are not intended behaviors, please consider to correct them in future releases.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Not global-trimming both front and tail simultaneously; I am using Fastp version 0.21.0. In my environment (Linux Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS), Fastp seems to fail to perform global-trimming for front and tail bases simultaneously. The command line `fastp –-in1 fq1.fq.gz –in2 fq2.fq.gz -f 8 -F 8 -t 8 -T 8` seems to perform global-trimming for only front 8bp sequences. Both ` fastp –-in1 fq1.fq.gz –in2 fq2.fq.gz -f 8 -F 8` and `fastp –-in1 fq1.fq.gz –in2 fq2.fq.gz -t 8 -T 8` worked well. Thus, `fastp --in1 fq1.fq.gz --in2 fq2.fq.gz --stdout -f 8 -F 8 | fastp --stdin --interleaved_in -t 8 -T 8` also worked well. If these are not intended behaviors, please consider to correct them in future releases.

author: OpenGene

sentence: --cut_right not working as expected; Hi guys,. I used the following command to call fastp:. ```bash. fastp -i reads/XXXXXXXXXXX_S81_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz -I reads/XXXXXXXXXXX_S81_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz -o R1.fastq.gz -O R2.fastq.gz --cut_right -M 30 --cut_right_window_size 1 -w 10. ```. I would expect that every basecall with a phred blow 30 and every later basecall is removed by fastp. If I analyze the output using fastQC I got such an unexpected behavior:. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25884974/121172725-47ab0680-c858-11eb-8fe6-bb929018699f.png). For me it looks like the last basecall of a reads is ignored by the sliding window by an off by one error. Installed fastp via conda (v0.20.1). Cheers! Ben.

author: OpenGene

sentence: Feature request for read pair merge precedure; Hi team. It seems like current fastp retains higher base quality sequencing base when perform read merge step. Example below (Please look the base 'N' in read 1 carefully). ```. >Read1. [NoOverlap1]GGTCTCNCT. +. [NoOverlap1]AAAAAA#AA. >Read2. [NoOverlap2]AGCGAGACC. +. [NoOverlap2]AAAAAAAAA. >Merged Read. [NoOverlap1]GGTCTCACT[NoOverlap2]. +. [NoOverlap1]AAAAAAAA[NoOverlap2]. ```. Current fastp has `--correction` option which only corrects the mismatched bases. In some field of study (such as variant calls from cell free DNA sequencing data analysis), this might cause false positive signal. My suggestion is make a new option such as `--mismatches-to-N` that converts all mismatched bases in a overlapped region into 'N' bases so that the typical variant callers can skip those reads for variant call. The desired output of above example is shown below. ```. >Merged with N-bases. [NoOverlap1]GGTCTCNCT[NoOverlap2]. +. [NoOverlap1]AAAAAA#AA[NoOverlap2]. ```

author: OpenGene

sentence: Extract UMIs from fastq1 3' end taking into account adapter sequence; Hi! I have paired-end data with the UMI located just before an index of 11 nt in the 5' of the fastq2 and after that index in the 3' of the fastq1. I share with you some reads of my fastqs:. Fastq2: UMIs are the first 12 nucleotides of the reads, followed by 11 nucleotides of the adapter (ATTGGAGTCCT). ```. read1. GATAAATGCATGATTGGAGTCCTTCATGGTACACCACACTCTGCACAATTCCATGGATTGGATTTAACAAATTTGGATCTTGGCACAATGATAACAGGGTGTTGATCTTAGAGTCCAACAAATTATGCCAAAACGCAATACTGTACATT. read2. ATGGTATAGACTATTGGAGTCCTCTGGAGGGCCGCTTTCGCCTGTCCCACGTCCTGCAAATGCAGTGCCTCTCGGATCTGGTGCAGCGACCCTTCTCCTGGCATCGTGGCATTTCCGAGATTGGAGCCTAACAGTGTAGATCCTGAGAACA. read3. GTCCGGATCGGAATTGGAGTCCTGCCCACAAAGGTTACGCAGAGACACCAACCTAGAATCCAGGAACGGGGACTGGCAGAGGCCTGGGTAGGAGTCCATTGGGCTGCTGGAGGGCAGATTGCCCAAAGGGAGTCCACCTACAAGACGGACA. ```. Fastq1: the reverse-complement sequence of UMIs is located in the last 12 nucleotides, after the reverse-complement of the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT). ```. read4. AGGACGCGGTTCTCGGTGAGTGTGTGGGCCACCTCGTCCTGTAAAGCAGGGCTGGGTGAGCTGCCACCCCGCACCCTCATCTCCACAGGACTCCAATATTCACAACTAG. read5. ATTAGGCAAGAGTTACTTACTACAGTTTTCTTCATCTGAATTATCACTGCAGTCATTTTGGCTATCACACCGCCAGTGATCGGGAAAGGACTCCAATCCTTATCGACGC. read6. TTACTAACCCGTCCTCTCGCTGTTAGACATCTCTCTCACTGCCTGTCTCTGGTTCTGTCCTCAGGCCACCCCTGTTCTCCGAGGACTCCAATCTGGTCGTCGAA. ```. I have to take into account the following issues:. . 1. I find the adapter and, therefore, the UMI in a higher proportion of reads in fastq1 than in fastq2, so I would like to use fastq1 to detect de UMIs. 2. The UMIs are located in the tail (3') of the fastq1, so I am not sure how to indicate that, because the option `read1` refers to the head of the read (5'). 3. I wish to detect the UMIs by using the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT) and not a fixed position, because in some reads the adapter and the UMI are not exactly in the tail, but some bases upstream. . With this information, I think the best option is to use:. fastp -i R1.fq -I

Fastq1: the reverse-complement sequence of UMIs is located in the last 12 nucleotides, after the reverse-complement of the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT). ```. read4. AGGACGCGGTTCTCGGTGAGTGTGTGGGCCACCTCGTCCTGTAAAGCAGGGCTGGGTGAGCTGCCACCCCGCACCCTCATCTCCACAGGACTCCAATATTCACAACTAG. read5. ATTAGGCAAGAGTTACTTACTACAGTTTTCTTCATCTGAATTATCACTGCAGTCATTTTGGCTATCACACCGCCAGTGATCGGGAAAGGACTCCAATCCTTATCGACGC. read6. TTACTAACCCGTCCTCTCGCTGTTAGACATCTCTCTCACTGCCTGTCTCTGGTTCTGTCCTCAGGCCACCCCTGTTCTCCGAGGACTCCAATCTGGTCGTCGAA. ```. I have to take into account the following issues:. . 1. I find the adapter and, therefore, the UMI in a higher proportion of reads in fastq1 than in fastq2, so I would like to use fastq1 to detect de UMIs. 2. The UMIs are located in the tail (3') of the fastq1, so I am not sure how to indicate that, because the option `read1` refers to the head of the read (5'). 3. I wish to detect the UMIs by using the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT) and not a fixed position, because in some reads the adapter and the UMI are not exactly in the tail, but some bases upstream. . With this information, I think the best option is to use:. fastp -i R1.fq -I

GTCCGGATCGGAATTGGAGTCCTGCCCACAAAGGTTACGCAGAGACACCAACCTAGAATCCAGGAACGGGGACTGGCAGAGGCCTGGGTAGGAGTCCATTGGGCTGCTGGAGGGCAGATTGCCCAAAGGGAGTCCACCTACAAGACGGACA. ```. Fastq1: the reverse-complement sequence of UMIs is located in the last 12 nucleotides, after the reverse-complement of the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT). ```. read4. AGGACGCGGTTCTCGGTGAGTGTGTGGGCCACCTCGTCCTGTAAAGCAGGGCTGGGTGAGCTGCCACCCCGCACCCTCATCTCCACAGGACTCCAATATTCACAACTAG. read5. ATTAGGCAAGAGTTACTTACTACAGTTTTCTTCATCTGAATTATCACTGCAGTCATTTTGGCTATCACACCGCCAGTGATCGGGAAAGGACTCCAATCCTTATCGACGC. read6. TTACTAACCCGTCCTCTCGCTGTTAGACATCTCTCTCACTGCCTGTCTCTGGTTCTGTCCTCAGGCCACCCCTGTTCTCCGAGGACTCCAATCTGGTCGTCGAA. ```. I have to take into account the following issues:. . 1. I find the adapter and, therefore, the UMI in a higher proportion of reads in fastq1 than in fastq2, so I would like to use fastq1 to detect de UMIs. 2. The UMIs are located in the tail (3') of the fastq1, so I am not sure how to indicate that, because the option `read1` refers to the head of the read (5'). 3. I wish to detect the UMIs by using the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT) and not a fixed position, because in some reads the adapter and the UMI are not exactly in the tail, but some bases upstream. . With this information, I think the best option is to use:. fastp -i R1.fq -I R2.fq -o out.R1.fq -O out.R2.fq-U --umi_loc=index1 . So do you think this is correct? How can I specify the sequence of the index1 (which I undestand is the adapter) and that this index is located in the 3' of the read? . . Thanks!

sentence: Extract UMIs from fastq1 3' end taking into account adapter sequence; Hi! I have paired-end data with the UMI located just before an index of 11 nt in the 5' of the fastq2 and after that index in the 3' of the fastq1. I share with you some reads of my fastqs:. Fastq2: UMIs are the first 12 nucleotides of the reads, followed by 11 nucleotides of the adapter (ATTGGAGTCCT). ```. read1. GATAAATGCATGATTGGAGTCCTTCATGGTACACCACACTCTGCACAATTCCATGGATTGGATTTAACAAATTTGGATCTTGGCACAATGATAACAGGGTGTTGATCTTAGAGTCCAACAAATTATGCCAAAACGCAATACTGTACATT. read2. ATGGTATAGACTATTGGAGTCCTCTGGAGGGCCGCTTTCGCCTGTCCCACGTCCTGCAAATGCAGTGCCTCTCGGATCTGGTGCAGCGACCCTTCTCCTGGCATCGTGGCATTTCCGAGATTGGAGCCTAACAGTGTAGATCCTGAGAACA. read3. GTCCGGATCGGAATTGGAGTCCTGCCCACAAAGGTTACGCAGAGACACCAACCTAGAATCCAGGAACGGGGACTGGCAGAGGCCTGGGTAGGAGTCCATTGGGCTGCTGGAGGGCAGATTGCCCAAAGGGAGTCCACCTACAAGACGGACA. ```. Fastq1: the reverse-complement sequence of UMIs is located in the last 12 nucleotides, after the reverse-complement of the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT). ```. read4. AGGACGCGGTTCTCGGTGAGTGTGTGGGCCACCTCGTCCTGTAAAGCAGGGCTGGGTGAGCTGCCACCCCGCACCCTCATCTCCACAGGACTCCAATATTCACAACTAG. read5. ATTAGGCAAGAGTTACTTACTACAGTTTTCTTCATCTGAATTATCACTGCAGTCATTTTGGCTATCACACCGCCAGTGATCGGGAAAGGACTCCAATCCTTATCGACGC. read6. TTACTAACCCGTCCTCTCGCTGTTAGACATCTCTCTCACTGCCTGTCTCTGGTTCTGTCCTCAGGCCACCCCTGTTCTCCGAGGACTCCAATCTGGTCGTCGAA. ```. I have to take into account the following issues:. . 1. I find the adapter and, therefore, the UMI in a higher proportion of reads in fastq1 than in fastq2, so I would like to use fastq1 to detect de UMIs. 2. The UMIs are located in the tail (3') of the fastq1, so I am not sure how to indicate that, because the option `read1` refers to the head of the read (5'). 3. I wish to detect the UMIs by using the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT) and not a fixed position, because in some reads the adapter and the UMI are not exactly in the tail, but some bases upstream. . With this information, I think the best option is to use:. fastp -i R1.fq -I
author: OpenGene

sentence: Extract UMIs from fastq1 3' end taking into account adapter sequence; Hi! I have paired-end data with the UMI located just before an index of 11 nt in the 5' of the fastq2 and after that index in the 3' of the fastq1. I share with you some reads of my fastqs:. Fastq2: UMIs are the first 12 nucleotides of the reads, followed by 11 nucleotides of the adapter (ATTGGAGTCCT). ```. read1. GATAAATGCATGATTGGAGTCCTTCATGGTACACCACACTCTGCACAATTCCATGGATTGGATTTAACAAATTTGGATCTTGGCACAATGATAACAGGGTGTTGATCTTAGAGTCCAACAAATTATGCCAAAACGCAATACTGTACATT. read2. ATGGTATAGACTATTGGAGTCCTCTGGAGGGCCGCTTTCGCCTGTCCCACGTCCTGCAAATGCAGTGCCTCTCGGATCTGGTGCAGCGACCCTTCTCCTGGCATCGTGGCATTTCCGAGATTGGAGCCTAACAGTGTAGATCCTGAGAACA. read3. GTCCGGATCGGAATTGGAGTCCTGCCCACAAAGGTTACGCAGAGACACCAACCTAGAATCCAGGAACGGGGACTGGCAGAGGCCTGGGTAGGAGTCCATTGGGCTGCTGGAGGGCAGATTGCCCAAAGGGAGTCCACCTACAAGACGGACA. ```. Fastq1: the reverse-complement sequence of UMIs is located in the last 12 nucleotides, after the reverse-complement of the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT). ```. read4. AGGACGCGGTTCTCGGTGAGTGTGTGGGCCACCTCGTCCTGTAAAGCAGGGCTGGGTGAGCTGCCACCCCGCACCCTCATCTCCACAGGACTCCAATATTCACAACTAG. read5. ATTAGGCAAGAGTTACTTACTACAGTTTTCTTCATCTGAATTATCACTGCAGTCATTTTGGCTATCACACCGCCAGTGATCGGGAAAGGACTCCAATCCTTATCGACGC. read6. TTACTAACCCGTCCTCTCGCTGTTAGACATCTCTCTCACTGCCTGTCTCTGGTTCTGTCCTCAGGCCACCCCTGTTCTCCGAGGACTCCAATCTGGTCGTCGAA. ```. I have to take into account the following issues:. . 1. I find the adapter and, therefore, the UMI in a higher proportion of reads in fastq1 than in fastq2, so I would like to use fastq1 to detect de UMIs. 2. The UMIs are located in the tail (3') of the fastq1, so I am not sure how to indicate that, because the option `read1` refers to the head of the read (5'). 3. I wish to detect the UMIs by using the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT) and not a fixed position, because in some reads the adapter and the UMI are not exactly in the tail, but some bases upstream. . With this information, I think the best option is to use:. fastp -i R1.fq -I

Fastq1: the reverse-complement sequence of UMIs is located in the last 12 nucleotides, after the reverse-complement of the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT). ```. read4. AGGACGCGGTTCTCGGTGAGTGTGTGGGCCACCTCGTCCTGTAAAGCAGGGCTGGGTGAGCTGCCACCCCGCACCCTCATCTCCACAGGACTCCAATATTCACAACTAG. read5. ATTAGGCAAGAGTTACTTACTACAGTTTTCTTCATCTGAATTATCACTGCAGTCATTTTGGCTATCACACCGCCAGTGATCGGGAAAGGACTCCAATCCTTATCGACGC. read6. TTACTAACCCGTCCTCTCGCTGTTAGACATCTCTCTCACTGCCTGTCTCTGGTTCTGTCCTCAGGCCACCCCTGTTCTCCGAGGACTCCAATCTGGTCGTCGAA. ```. I have to take into account the following issues:. . 1. I find the adapter and, therefore, the UMI in a higher proportion of reads in fastq1 than in fastq2, so I would like to use fastq1 to detect de UMIs. 2. The UMIs are located in the tail (3') of the fastq1, so I am not sure how to indicate that, because the option `read1` refers to the head of the read (5'). 3. I wish to detect the UMIs by using the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT) and not a fixed position, because in some reads the adapter and the UMI are not exactly in the tail, but some bases upstream. . With this information, I think the best option is to use:. fastp -i R1.fq -I R2.fq -o out.R1.fq -O out.R2.fq-U --umi_loc=index1 . So do you think this is correct? How can I specify the sequence of the index1 (which I undestand is the adapter) and that this index is located in the 3' of the read? . . Thanks!

sentence: Extract UMIs from fastq1 3' end taking into account adapter sequence; Hi! I have paired-end data with the UMI located just before an index of 11 nt in the 5' of the fastq2 and after that index in the 3' of the fastq1. I share with you some reads of my fastqs:. Fastq2: UMIs are the first 12 nucleotides of the reads, followed by 11 nucleotides of the adapter (ATTGGAGTCCT). ```. read1. GATAAATGCATGATTGGAGTCCTTCATGGTACACCACACTCTGCACAATTCCATGGATTGGATTTAACAAATTTGGATCTTGGCACAATGATAACAGGGTGTTGATCTTAGAGTCCAACAAATTATGCCAAAACGCAATACTGTACATT. read2. ATGGTATAGACTATTGGAGTCCTCTGGAGGGCCGCTTTCGCCTGTCCCACGTCCTGCAAATGCAGTGCCTCTCGGATCTGGTGCAGCGACCCTTCTCCTGGCATCGTGGCATTTCCGAGATTGGAGCCTAACAGTGTAGATCCTGAGAACA. read3. GTCCGGATCGGAATTGGAGTCCTGCCCACAAAGGTTACGCAGAGACACCAACCTAGAATCCAGGAACGGGGACTGGCAGAGGCCTGGGTAGGAGTCCATTGGGCTGCTGGAGGGCAGATTGCCCAAAGGGAGTCCACCTACAAGACGGACA. ```. Fastq1: the reverse-complement sequence of UMIs is located in the last 12 nucleotides, after the reverse-complement of the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT). ```. read4. AGGACGCGGTTCTCGGTGAGTGTGTGGGCCACCTCGTCCTGTAAAGCAGGGCTGGGTGAGCTGCCACCCCGCACCCTCATCTCCACAGGACTCCAATATTCACAACTAG. read5. ATTAGGCAAGAGTTACTTACTACAGTTTTCTTCATCTGAATTATCACTGCAGTCATTTTGGCTATCACACCGCCAGTGATCGGGAAAGGACTCCAATCCTTATCGACGC. read6. TTACTAACCCGTCCTCTCGCTGTTAGACATCTCTCTCACTGCCTGTCTCTGGTTCTGTCCTCAGGCCACCCCTGTTCTCCGAGGACTCCAATCTGGTCGTCGAA. ```. I have to take into account the following issues:. . 1. I find the adapter and, therefore, the UMI in a higher proportion of reads in fastq1 than in fastq2, so I would like to use fastq1 to detect de UMIs. 2. The UMIs are located in the tail (3') of the fastq1, so I am not sure how to indicate that, because the option `read1` refers to the head of the read (5'). 3. I wish to detect the UMIs by using the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT) and not a fixed position, because in some reads the adapter and the UMI are not exactly in the tail, but some bases upstream. . With this information, I think the best option is to use:. fastp -i R1.fq -I

sentence: ou some reads of my fastqs:. Fastq2: UMIs are the first 12 nucleotides of the reads, followed by 11 nucleotides of the adapter (ATTGGAGTCCT). ```. read1. GATAAATGCATGATTGGAGTCCTTCATGGTACACCACACTCTGCACAATTCCATGGATTGGATTTAACAAATTTGGATCTTGGCACAATGATAACAGGGTGTTGATCTTAGAGTCCAACAAATTATGCCAAAACGCAATACTGTACATT. read2. ATGGTATAGACTATTGGAGTCCTCTGGAGGGCCGCTTTCGCCTGTCCCACGTCCTGCAAATGCAGTGCCTCTCGGATCTGGTGCAGCGACCCTTCTCCTGGCATCGTGGCATTTCCGAGATTGGAGCCTAACAGTGTAGATCCTGAGAACA. read3. GTCCGGATCGGAATTGGAGTCCTGCCCACAAAGGTTACGCAGAGACACCAACCTAGAATCCAGGAACGGGGACTGGCAGAGGCCTGGGTAGGAGTCCATTGGGCTGCTGGAGGGCAGATTGCCCAAAGGGAGTCCACCTACAAGACGGACA. ```. Fastq1: the reverse-complement sequence of UMIs is located in the last 12 nucleotides, after the reverse-complement of the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT). ```. read4. AGGACGCGGTTCTCGGTGAGTGTGTGGGCCACCTCGTCCTGTAAAGCAGGGCTGGGTGAGCTGCCACCCCGCACCCTCATCTCCACAGGACTCCAATATTCACAACTAG. read5. ATTAGGCAAGAGTTACTTACTACAGTTTTCTTCATCTGAATTATCACTGCAGTCATTTTGGCTATCACACCGCCAGTGATCGGGAAAGGACTCCAATCCTTATCGACGC. read6. TTACTAACCCGTCCTCTCGCTGTTAGACATCTCTCTCACTGCCTGTCTCTGGTTCTGTCCTCAGGCCACCCCTGTTCTCCGAGGACTCCAATCTGGTCGTCGAA. ```. I have to take into account the following issues:. . 1. I find the adapter and, therefore, the UMI in a higher proportion of reads in fastq1 than in fastq2, so I would like to use fastq1 to detect de UMIs. 2. The UMIs are located in the tail (3') of the fastq1, so I am not sure how to indicate that, because the option `read1` refers to the head of the read (5'). 3. I wish to detect the UMIs by using the adapter (AGGACTCCAAT) and not a fixed position, because in some reads the adapter and the UMI are not exactly in the tail, but some bases upstream. . With this information, I think the best option is to use:. fastp -i R1.fq -I R2.fq -o out.R1.fq -O out.R2.fq-U --umi_loc=index1 . So do you think this is correct? How can I specify the sequence of the index1 (which I undestand is the adapter) and that this index is located in the 3' of the read? . . Thanks!

sentence: Failed to compile in 0.21.1; Hello,. The latest commit seems to have added a bug in the compilation. I am not familiar with cpp so I have no clue what's happening, I've attached the error and the g++ version below. ```bash. g++ -c src/stats.cpp -o obj/stats.o -std=c++11 -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/htmlreporter.cpp -o obj/htmlreporter.o -std=c++11 -g -O3 -I./inc . In file included from src/htmlreporter.cpp:1:. src/htmlreporter.h:20:24: error: ‘atomic_long’ has not been declared. void setInsertHist(atomic_long* insertHist, int insertSizePeak);. ^~~~~~~~~~~. sentence: JSON formatting error - quotes in report name not escaped; . If a quoted string is passed to the -R flag (to allow spaces in the report title), _e.g._. `fastp -i raw_data/566136_S11.fastq.gz -o raw_data/566136_S11.trimmed_fastp.fastq.gz -w 8 -p -j 566136_S11_fastp.json -h 566136_S11.html -R "566136_S11 fastp report"`. The quotes around the report title are not escaped in the json "command" line, resulting in the following:. `	"command": "fastp -i raw_data/566136_S11.fastq.gz -o raw_data/566136_S11.trimmed_fastp.fastq.gz -w 8 -p -j 566136_S11_fastp.json -h 566136_S11.html -R "566136_S11 fastp report" ". `. This leads to an error when parsing the JSON file. Thanks,. Chris. Version: 0.20.1

If a quoted string is passed to the -R flag (to allow spaces in the report title), _e.g._. `fastp -i raw_data/566136_S11.fastq.gz -o raw_data/566136_S11.trimmed_fastp.fastq.gz -w 8 -p -j 566136_S11_fastp.json -h 566136_S11.html -R "566136_S11 fastp report"`. The quotes around the report title are not escaped in the json "command" line, resulting in the following:. `	"command": "fastp -i raw_data/566136_S11.fastq.gz -o raw_data/566136_S11.trimmed_fastp.fastq.gz -w 8 -p -j 566136_S11_fastp.json -h 566136_S11.html -R "566136_S11 fastp report" ". `. This leads to an error when parsing the JSON file. Thanks,. Chris. Version: 0.20.1
author: OpenGene

sentence: run the same fastp command but get different result of clean fastq files; I use Ubuntu 16.04 on a server, use fastp v0.20.1 to do QC, but I find that I get different clean read data files. For example, today 10:00 am I run fastp for raw sequencing data, I get clean fastq files; today 14:00 pm I run the same program again, and I get the clean fastq files of which the contents are different from 10:00 am. Please tell me why and how can I get the same clean fastq files even if I run many times program. The bash command is below:. `/home/tang/anaconda3/envs/transcript_env/bin/fastp . --in1 CF1.R1.raw.fq . --in2 CF1.R2.raw.fq . --out1 CF1.R1.clean.fq . --out2 CF1.R2.clean.fq . --thread 4 . --trim_front1 2 . --trim_front2 2 . --cut_front . --cut_tail . --cut_window_size 3 . --cut_mean_quality 30 . --json CF1.json . --html CF1.html . --overrepresentation_analysis `
author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp - filtering for merged-read lengths; Hello OpenGene,. Thanks for this very useful QC tool. Similar to the existing quality filtering, it would be very helpful for our data processing and trouble-shooting applications if there would be an option to filter the data for merged-read lengths. It would be best If one could compare the data analysis results (e.g. quality scores) before and after merged-read length filtering. Lutz
author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp does not read bash variable; Hello, I'm attempting to run fastp like this:. `READ1=test_R1`. `READ2=test_R2`. `fastp -i $READ1.fastq.gz -I $READ2.fastq.gz -o $READ1.qc.fastq.gz -O $READ2.qc.fastq.gz`. However, fastp ignores the variables and attempts to find ".fastq.gz". I'm using the precompiled Linux binary. Guessing this is not the intended behavior so reporting here.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Changed the typedefs for (u)int64 to (unsigned) long long for mingw; There is a problem when compiling with MinGW64 as specified. . When running no output is generated due to a an overflow that later causes a division by 0 because in MinGW long is only 32 bits, on Linux it's 64.

sentence: Multithreading failed; Hi,. With fastp 0.23.0, in a Docker image with Centos7. When using a simple command:. ```. fastp --in1=Sample3.R1.fastq.gz --in2=Sample3.R2.fastq.gz --out1=Sample3.fastp.R1.fastq.gz --out2=Sample3.fastp.R2.fastq.gz. ```. I obtain this error message:. ```. terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::system_error'. what(): Enable multithreading to use std::thread: Operation not permitted. Aborted. ```. I tried with "--thread=1", "--thread=2"... but same message. Apparently, it worked with fastp release 0.22.0. Do you have a solution?
author: OpenGene

sentence: How to pull by version?; I built fastp in a docker image and it was working with v0.22.0 (it currently works on my local machine however I build that docker image over a week ago); however with issue #361 when I build a docker image in my CI/CD on AWS and then run a batch job I get the multithreading error. In my dockerfile I have,. ```. RUN wget http://opengene.org/fastp/fastp && \. chmod a+x ./fastp && \. cp fastp /bin/fastp. ```. Is it possible to pin v0.22.0? when I download from http://opengene.org/fastp/fastp?
author: OpenGene

sentence: How to pull by version?; I built fastp in a docker image and it was working with v0.22.0 (it currently works on my local machine however I build that docker image over a week ago); however with issue #361 when I build a docker image in my CI/CD on AWS and then run a batch job I get the multithreading error. In my dockerfile I have,. ```. RUN wget http://opengene.org/fastp/fastp && \. chmod a+x ./fastp && \. cp fastp /bin/fastp. ```. Is it possible to pin v0.22.0? when I download from http://opengene.org/fastp/fastp?

sentence: why the new version is slower; fastp v0.20.0, time used: 358 seconds . fastp v0.22.0, time used: 481 seconds . The fastq file is the same. Worker compute is the same. Moreover, solid state drives and mechanical drives have no advantage in running speed.
author: OpenGene

sentence: .JSON File (v0.23.1): Understanding after_filtering Vs filtering_result.; Dear Fastp, . I would like to kindly ask for some clarification regarding the results presented in the .JSON file. Specifically, I would like to know what is the difference between the `total_reads` [after_filtering] and the `passed_filter_reads` [filtering_result]. My intuition tells me that these numbers should be the same, and I believe that that is what you have [in your example](http://opengene.org/fastp/fastp.json). However, my two numbers are different and I do not quite understand why. ```. "sequencing": "paired end (150 cycles + 150 cycles)",. "before_filtering": {. "total_reads":6510970,. "total_bases":976645500,. "q20_bases":920167817,. "q30_bases":853405681,. "q20_rate":0.942172,. "q30_rate":0.873813,. "read1_mean_length":150,. "read2_mean_length":150,. "gc_content":0.440688. },. "after_filtering": {. "total_reads":1176646,. "total_bases":183937612,. "q20_bases":179080377,. "q30_bases":170016138,. "q20_rate":0.973593,. "q30_rate":0.924314,. "read1_mean_length":156,. "gc_content":0.434624. }. },. "filtering_result": {. "passed_filter_reads": 6312238,. "corrected_reads": 256148,. "corrected_bases": 621598,. "low_quality_reads": 172442,. "too_many_N_reads": 2,. "low_complexity_reads": 1930,. "too_short_reads": 24358,. "too_long_reads": 0. ```. . I have been using [MultiQC](https://github.com/ewels/MultiQC) to aggregate the results obtained by Fastp, and I would like to make sure it is feeding on the correct numbers reported by Fastp. Please let me know should you require any further information from my end. Thankful in advance, George.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Compile error is src/read.cpp; On CentOS 7 I had to add:. #include <string.h>. to src/read.cpp to get it to compile. Here is what I got before adding that line:. ```. g++ -c src/read.cpp -o obj/read.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . src/read.cpp: In member function ‘void Read::appendToString(std::string*)’:. src/read.cpp:125:52: error: ‘memcpy’ was not declared in this scope. memcpy(str + total, mName->data(), mName->length());. ^. src/read.cpp: In member function ‘void Read::appendToStringWithTag(std::string*, std::string)’:. src/read.cpp:151:52: error: ‘memcpy’ was not declared in this scope. memcpy(str + total, mName->data(), mName->length());. ^. make: *** [Makefile:32: obj/read.o] Error 1. ```
author: OpenGene

Here is what I got before adding that line:. ```. g++ -c src/read.cpp -o obj/read.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . src/read.cpp: In member function ‘void Read::appendToString(std::string*)’:. src/read.cpp:125:52: error: ‘memcpy’ was not declared in this scope. memcpy(str + total, mName->data(), mName->length());. ^. src/read.cpp: In member function ‘void Read::appendToStringWithTag(std::string*, std::string)’:. src/read.cpp:151:52: error: ‘memcpy’ was not declared in this scope. memcpy(str + total, mName->data(), mName->length());. ^. make: *** [Makefile:32: obj/read.o] Error 1. ```

sentence: Filtered reads not written to file; Hi. I'm running `fastp` on PE data with the `--out1`, `--out2`, `--unpaired1`, `--unpaired2`, and `--failed_out` flags. `fastp` reports that `reads failed due to too short: 32` and indeed if I check the output files I am missing 16 forward and 16 reverse reads. However, the failed and unpaired output files are all empty. I was expecting to see these 32 reads in one of these files. . Should all reads be accounted for or is there a situation where a read is not ultimately written to any of the output files?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Fix compile error on some Linux distros; Hi,. Compiling fastp from source can fail on AlmaLinux 8.4 (CentOS stable derivative) with the message `error: ‘memcpy’ was not declared in this scope` (see related issue #368 for more details). Adding `#include <cstring>` to src/read.cpp fixes the problem. Thanks for creating and maintaining a very useful software!

author: OpenGene

sentence: base content line crossed at the tail; I have some concatenated fq for quality control. When I check the report, I found something unexplained. . The GC/AT base content line crossed at around 90 bp. . ![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81213192/140633157-4d6aaafc-5823-4f1b-8946-130bdba0c5c5.png). After using fastp -f 15 -t 15 to trim the front and tail, the base content line crossed again at around 60bp (originally 75bp before filtering). . ![2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81213192/140633278-1aee0c2b-b219-4e68-a318-11b13ed14eab.png). The code I used: . `fastp --thread 8 --qualified_quality_phred 20 -f 15 -t 15 --cut_right --cut_window_size 4 --cut_mean_quality 20 --unqualified_percent_limit 40 --n_base_limit 5 --compression 4 -i ./data/test.fastq.gz -o ./data/test_clean.fastq.gz -h ./data/test.html -j ./data/test.json --detect_adapter_for_pe`. I suspected the crossing does not result from low quality bases at the tail. But I can't explain why the cross point appeared earlier after filtering. . May I ask why this happens? How to solve this? . Thank you. .
author: OpenGene

The GC/AT base content line crossed at around 90 bp. . ![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81213192/140633157-4d6aaafc-5823-4f1b-8946-130bdba0c5c5.png). After using fastp -f 15 -t 15 to trim the front and tail, the base content line crossed again at around 60bp (originally 75bp before filtering). . ![2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81213192/140633278-1aee0c2b-b219-4e68-a318-11b13ed14eab.png). The code I used: . `fastp --thread 8 --qualified_quality_phred 20 -f 15 -t 15 --cut_right --cut_window_size 4 --cut_mean_quality 20 --unqualified_percent_limit 40 --n_base_limit 5 --compression 4 -i ./data/test.fastq.gz -o ./data/test_clean.fastq.gz -h ./data/test.html -j ./data/test.json --detect_adapter_for_pe`. I suspected the crossing does not result from low quality bases at the tail. But I can't explain why the cross point appeared earlier after filtering. . May I ask why this happens? How to solve this? . Thank you. .

sentence: fastp version 0.23.0 and above failed to process interleaved Fastq files; Dr, chen,. when process interleaved fastq, fastp version 0.23.0 and 0.23.1 segment fault or hangs. but using version 0.22.0 and other older versions, it works smoothly. please verify this issue.

sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21733 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-009. Detecting adapter sequence for read1...
author: OpenGene

sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. author: OpenGene

sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21733 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-009. Detecting adapter sequence for read1...

author: OpenGene

sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21733 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-009. Detecting adapter sequence for read1...

author: OpenGene

sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21733 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-009. Detecting adapter sequence for read1...

author: OpenGene

sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21733 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-009. Detecting adapter sequence for read1...

Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21890 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. I'm running fastp v 0.21.0 on an Ubuntu 18.x machine. Please let me know what you think the error might be due to. Many thanks! Follow-up: I just tried the same commands on the same files with v 0.23 and it doesn't give the segmentation fault error, but files that are 30-60MB (gzipped) are produced and fastp hangs and doesn't complete processing the file.

sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21733 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-009. Detecting adapter sequence for read1...

author: OpenGene

sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21733 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-009. Detecting adapter sequence for read1...

Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21733 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-009. Detecting adapter sequence for read1...

author: OpenGene

sentence: segmentation fault: core dumped during adapter trimming; Hello, I am using fastp to clean my reads before alignment. I am currently processing 48 samples as part of a bash workflow, and two files have given me a segmentation fault error, and they are not the two largest files of the 48 (each read file is ~1.2GB). I watch my memory consumption and it does not get maxed out (64GB RAM available). Here is the command I used:. for SAMPLE_ID in ${SAMPLENAMES}; do. 	printf "\nPIPELINE ALERT: Trimming %s\n" "${SAMPLE_ID}". 	${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz\. 		--out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz\. 		--detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction\. 		--cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20\. 		--html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". 	rm ./fastp.json;. done. And here is the screen output (with some of my own workflow output) with the error for both files:. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-008. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21733 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-009. Detecting adapter sequence for read1...

Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21733 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. PIPELINE ALERT: Trimming CW-N-009. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. Error to read gzip file. 0809.sh: line 7: 21890 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ${FASTP} --in1 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1.fastq.gz --in2 ${RAWREADSDIR}/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2.fastq.gz --out1 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R1_clean.fq.gz --out2 ${OUTDIR}/${POP}/Clean_fastqs/${SAMPLE_ID}_R2_clean.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -q ${PHREDQ} -u ${BADBASES} -l ${MINREADLENGTH} --correction --cut_right --cut_right_window_size 4 --cut_right_mean_quality 20 --html "${OUTDIR}/${POP}/FastqQC/${SAMPLE_ID}_fastq_trim_report.html". rm: cannot remove './fastp.json': No such file or directory. I'm running fastp v 0.21.0 on an Ubuntu 18.x machine. Please let me know what you think the error might be due to. Many thanks! Follow-up: I just tried the same commands on the same files with v 0.23 and it doesn't give the segmentation fault error, but files that are 30-60MB (gzipped) are produced and fastp hangs and doesn't complete processing the file.

sentence: Warning label: different read numbers in pack; Hi I was hoping you could clarify a warning label that I got:. >fastp --in1 /Users/beatrizamorim/Desktop/mtDNA/data/DEMI115_R1.fastq.gz \. --in2 /Users/beatrizamorim/Desktop/mtDNA/data/DEMI115_R2.fastq.gz \. --detect_adapter_for_pe \. -c \. -p \. --qualified_quality_phred 30 \. --dedup --out1 DEMI115_R1.qc.fq.gz \. --out2 DEMI115_R2.qc.fq.gz \. --unpaired1 singletons.DEMI115.qc.fq.gz \. --unpaired2 singletons.DEMI115.qc.fq.gz \. --failed_out failed.DEMI115.qc.fq.gz \. --json fastp.DEMI115.json \. --html fastp.DEMI115.html \. --thread 4. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. WARNNIG: different read numbers of the 932 pack. Read1 pack size: 1000. Read2 pack size: 91. This is the first time I get an error like this, all the samples before this one didnt have any problem. The program got stuck on this error. . Does this mean there is something wrong with my reads? Should I exclude this sample altogether? i am using version: 0.23.1

Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... >Illumina TruSeq Adapter Read 2. AGATCGGAAGAGCGTCGTGTAGGGAAAGAGTGT. WARNNIG: different read numbers of the 932 pack. Read1 pack size: 1000. Read2 pack size: 91. This is the first time I get an error like this, all the samples before this one didnt have any problem. The program got stuck on this error. . Does this mean there is something wrong with my reads? Should I exclude this sample altogether? i am using version: 0.23.1
author: OpenGene

sentence: Threading randomness issue in STDOUT mode.; Threading randomness issue in fastq files is reproducible, but the output is still randomly in stdout because using fwrite to STDOUT in multi-threading. . I am using fastp 0.23.1.
author: OpenGene

sentence: How to switch off --n_base_limit; I would like not to filter reads based on the number of "N" letters. To do this, I set "--n_base_limit=1000". However, fastp exits with the following error:. > ERROR: N base limit (--n_base_limit) should be 0 ~ 50, suggest 3 ~ 10. How can I switch off N-filtering entirely?

sentence: How to get the duplication rate; Dear fastp developers,. I found it is hard for me to understand how your guys get the duplication rate:. For example, this is a part of json data of my result:. ```. "duplication": {. 		"rate": 0.910521,. 		"histogram": [1130624,106970,74574,65064,61667,61438,63137,65810,68598,73119,77269,81962,85768,90070,94178,97218,98552,98275,98077,95173,91234,85494,78971,72084,64646,56487,49656,42317,36069,29938,115758],. 		"mean_gc": [0.217115,0.361388,0.39505,0.401536,0.403539,0.40217,0.401784,0.398806,0.396604,0.396175,0.39393,0.390689,0.391327,0.390688,0.390526,0.391602,0.389994,0.391571,0.39177,0.391223,0.392879,0.39365,0.394788,0.395048,0.39493,0.396148,0.396986,0.398778,0.398411,0.399165,0.402663]. 	},. 	"insert_size": {. 		"peak": 252,. 		"unknown": 2336003,. 		"histogram": . ```. Is it means that there are 1130624 reads are unique? And around 2163185 reads contain more than one more same reads or called duplication reads. According to the histogram, the percentage of unique reads is 34.32%, and duplicate reads is around 65.6%. So, why the duplication rate is 91.11%? I know the calculation method of duplication rate must be not as simple as I said. Could you explain simply? Looking forward your reply.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Segmentation Fault on interleaved fq files; Thank you for making this very useful tool! . I am experiencing an error when using interleaved fastq files:. ```shell. $ fastp -i fastqs_interleave/S1IP_1_val_hg38__interleave.fastq --interleaved_in. Segmentation fault (core dumped). ```. This error only happens in v0.23.0 and v0.23.1 -- downgrading to v0.22.0 fixes the issue.
author: OpenGene

I am experiencing an error when using interleaved fastq files:. ```shell. $ fastp -i fastqs_interleave/S1IP_1_val_hg38__interleave.fastq --interleaved_in. Segmentation fault (core dumped). ```. This error only happens in v0.23.0 and v0.23.1 -- downgrading to v0.22.0 fixes the issue.

sentence: Unable to download the latest version; Dear all,. I am using Mac M1 processor and it is giving me a hard time updating FASTP without conda. With conda I am able to update the FASTP however the latest version is 0.19. It will be admirable if you will be able to publish the latest version in conda as well. Best regards and thank you.

sentence: plotly.js resource fails to load when served over HTTPS; This breaks when the content is being served over HTTPS:. https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/blob/254ec78538eee62b3f2627505d606d99000241d2/src/htmlreporter.cpp#L407. ---. opengene.org will happily serve over HTTPS - so this is easily fixed by updating the URL to:. `https://opengene.org/plotly-1.2.0.min.js`. ---. ### More info. Browser console:. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42562517/146097288-efe54cf1-6d6c-492b-9613-6e1e2097cb1f.png). Report HTML:. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42562517/146097332-7ffbfda5-4455-442c-9619-cdd71ed45455.png).
author: OpenGene

sentence: Update plotly.js URL to HTTPS; Resolves issue [#322](https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/issues/322). This allows fastp result HTML to display properly over HTTPS.

sentence: Paired-end output files are shuffled; When running `fastp` on input files and using the trimmed results to align with `bwa`, I get the following error:. `[mem_sam_pe] paired reads have different names: "M03704:23:000000000-JWCTN:1:2108:20369:8375", "M03704:23:000000000-JWCTN:1:2110:20520:13940"`. I can then see that the forward and reverse files are in a different order:. ```. ngs/test/run2$ head -1 tmp/trim/01/*.fq. ==> tmp/trim/01/fw.fq <==. @M03704:23:000000000-JWCTN:1:2105:26234:19243 1:N:0:36. ==> tmp/trim/01/rv.fq <==. @M03704:23:000000000-JWCTN:1:1104:7450:12048 2:N:0:36. ```. I use version 0.23.2 from Conda. I'll see if I can make a minimal example
author: OpenGene

I can then see that the forward and reverse files are in a different order:. ```. ngs/test/run2$ head -1 tmp/trim/01/*.fq. ==> tmp/trim/01/fw.fq <==. @M03704:23:000000000-JWCTN:1:2105:26234:19243 1:N:0:36. ==> tmp/trim/01/rv.fq <==. @M03704:23:000000000-JWCTN:1:1104:7450:12048 2:N:0:36. ```. I can then see that the forward and reverse files are in a different order:. ```. ngs/test/run2$ head -1 tmp/trim/01/*.fq. ==> tmp/trim/01/fw.fq <==. @M03704:23:000000000-JWCTN:1:2105:26234:19243 1:N:0:36. ==> tmp/trim/01/rv.fq <==. @M03704:23:000000000-JWCTN:1:1104:7450:12048 2:N:0:36. ```. I use version 0.23.2 from Conda. I'll see if I can make a minimal example
author: OpenGene

sentence: Feature request: filter by pattern match; Thanks for the tool, it's great! Would it be possible to implement a filtering strategy based on pattern matching on read sequence, to only include/exclude reads based on e.g. regex? Ideally, you could filter by either/both R1 and R2 and choose whether to keep/discard the mate of a matching read. It's something at the moment I'm doing with two independent runs of `seqkit grep`, followed by a mate-fixing step, but it would be great to integrate everything in a single fastp call
author: OpenGene

sentence: how to skip the "--json" and "--html" report; Hi all,. When I deal with a big fastq file (>20G), it takes long time to generate the .json and .html reports. Is there any way to skip this step ? Thanks.
author: OpenGene

sentence: memory steadily increases as run continues; There were other issues about memory, but none resolved/addressed what I am seeing. I run fastp 0.23.2 in a stream as follows. . ```. fastp \. --stdin --interleaved_in --stdout \. --dont_eval_duplication \. --length_required 25 \. --merge --include_unmerged --correction \. --html mySample.html --json mySample.json \. --report_title mySample 2>/dev/null |. ```. Memory usage continually climbs as long as the job runs. On large data sets I am getting OOM job kills on my cluster. The job below went from RES 4.9g to 5.3g as I typed this message... (%CPU is low at the moment I captured this because the downstream task is busy - fastp is, indeed, much faster than the aligner!). ```. PID USER PR NI VIRT RES SHR S %CPU %MEM TIME+ COMMAND . 89783 wilsonte 20 0 5306760 4.9g 1828 S 2.0 2.6 49:47.81 fastp. ```. Is this expected behavior? Memory leak? User error?
author: OpenGene

PID USER PR NI VIRT RES SHR S %CPU %MEM TIME+ COMMAND . 89783 wilsonte 20 0 5306760 4.9g 1828 S 2.0 2.6 49:47.81 fastp. ```. Is this expected behavior? Memory leak? User error?

author: OpenGene

sentence: Doubt with --adapter_fasta parameter; Hello,. I have doubts about the operation of the "--adapter_fasta" parameter. . I am working with some datasets for which I cannot always know the adapters used. My idea was to pass a fasta with all the typical Illumina adapters: https://support.illumina.com/bulletins/2016/12/what-sequences-do-i-use-for-adapter-trimming.html. My doubt is whether this would be acceptable, as I'm worried that it could take away more than one of the adapters in some cases. For instance, trim de Truseq and the Nextera Illumina Adapters. Thanks in advance. Best regards.
author: OpenGene

My doubt is whether this would be acceptable, as I'm worried that it could take away more than one of the adapters in some cases. For instance, trim de Truseq and the Nextera Illumina Adapters. Thanks in advance. Best regards.

sentence: disable all filters but --trim_poly_g ; Hey OpenGene team,. I am using fastp to trim polyG in NextSeq reads. That is the only filtering I am interested at this point. I am wondering if with these settings below I am effectively just trimming polyG of if fastp is doing some additional filtering. . ```. fastp \ . --in1 R1.fastq.gz --out1 R1.no_polyg.fastq.gz \. --in2 R2.fastq.gz --out2 R2.no_polyg.fastq.gz \. --disable_quality_filtering \. --disable_length_filtering \. --disable_adapter_trimming \. --trim_poly_g \. --n_base_limit 50 \. --html report.remove_polyg.html. ```. Many thanks. Jorge

sentence: fastp FILTER results??; The relationship between character and Q score:. - !=05. - 4=19. - 5=20. - 6=21. - ?=30. To understand the mechanism of fastp trimming reads, I design a fastq file: `test.fastq`. the @line indicate the median and mean Q value of the read:. ```bash. @median=17.5;mean=17.5. GGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG. +. ??????????????????!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! @median=30;mean=18.89. GGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG. +. ????????????????????!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! @median=20;mean=20.17. GGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG. +. 666666666666655555555555555554444444. @median=20;mean=19.81. GGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG. +. 555555555555555554444444444444666666. ```. Then I run the code:. ```bash. fastp -i test.fastq -q 10 -o out.fastq. ```. The results:. ```bash. @median=20;mean=20.17. GGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG. +. 666666666666655555555555555554444444. @median=20;mean=19.81. GGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG. +. 555555555555555554444444444444666666. ```. It was weird! And I do not know how to read C++, so I really do not understand why it turns out like this. I set the cutoff of Q value should be 10. And I thought `fastp` would trim bases with low quality (like: !), but it just delete all read install of bases with low quality.

sentence: fastp needs a directory to write output sequences; Minor thing that I've found through trial and error for fastp-v0.19.5 & fastp-v0.20.1 . I cannot install the latest version of fastp; different issue: https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/issues/383#issuecomment-1088442268. Regardless, here is the behavior I've noticed:. fastp requires a directory to exist before you can write the output file in a different directory. . For example, given a directory of samples where the directory "fastq" is the parent directory, and each sample directory contains paired reads, and lastly the intended target directory is currently empty output directory (trimmed/). ```. data/. |__ fastq/. | |. | |__ sample_SRS111/. | | SRR119read1.fq.gz. | | SRR119read2.fq.gz. | |. | |__ sample_SRS112/. | SRS219read1.fq.gz. | SRS219read2.fq.gz. |. |__ trimmed/. |. |__ bash-scripts/. fastp_trim.sh. ```. and given the basic fastp command:. ```. fastp . -i data/fastq/sample_SRS111/SRR119read1.fq.gz . -o data/trimmed/sample_SRR111/SRR119_r1.fq.gz . -I data/fastq/sample_SRS111/SRR119read2.fq.gz . -O data/trimmed/sample_SRR111/SRR119_r2.fq.gz. ```. fastp will not write the file unless there is a directory available for the output of fastp. It expects the directory to look like this:. ```. data/. |. |__ fastq/. | |. | |__ sample_SRS111/. | | SRR119read1.fq.gz. | | SRR119read2.fq.gz. | |. | |__ sample_SRS112/. | SRS219read1.fq.gz. | SRS219read2.fq.gz. |. |__ trimmed/. | |__ sample_SRS111/. | |. | |__ sample_SRS112/. | . |__ bash-scripts/. fastp_trim.sh. ```. This behavior may be intended, but I did not see it documented.

For example, given a directory of samples where the directory "fastq" is the parent directory, and each sample directory contains paired reads, and lastly the intended target directory is currently empty output directory (trimmed/). ```. data/. |__ fastq/. | |. | |__ sample_SRS111/. | | SRR119read1.fq.gz. | | SRR119read2.fq.gz. | |. | |__ sample_SRS112/. | SRS219read1.fq.gz. | SRS219read2.fq.gz. |. |__ trimmed/. |. |__ bash-scripts/. fastp_trim.sh. ```. and given the basic fastp command:. ```. fastp . -i data/fastq/sample_SRS111/SRR119read1.fq.gz . -o data/trimmed/sample_SRR111/SRR119_r1.fq.gz . -I data/fastq/sample_SRS111/SRR119read2.fq.gz . -O data/trimmed/sample_SRR111/SRR119_r2.fq.gz. ```. fastp will not write the file unless there is a directory available for the output of fastp. It expects the directory to look like this:. ```. data/. |. |__ fastq/. | |. | |__ sample_SRS111/. | | SRR119read1.fq.gz. | | SRR119read2.fq.gz. | |. | |__ sample_SRS112/. | SRS219read1.fq.gz. | SRS219read2.fq.gz. |. |__ trimmed/. | |__ sample_SRS111/. | |. | |__ sample_SRS112/. | . |__ bash-scripts/. fastp_trim.sh. ```. This behavior may be intended, but I did not see it documented.

author: OpenGene

sentence: Check paired reads; Hello,. Could you please add a check of the correspondence between the 2 files "read1 / read2"? By mistake if we provide two unrelated files no error is returned. And it is the next step of our pipeline that highlights the problem: BWA returns "paired reads have different names". Example:. Inputs :. - sample1_R1.fq.gz => 4218837 reads. - sample2_R1.fq.gz => 4184393 reads. Fastp output :. - sample1_fastp_R1.fq.gz => 3973376 reads. - sample2_fastp_R1.fq.gz => 3973376 reads. Fastp log :. ```. Read1 before filtering:. total reads: 4184393. total bases: 627658950. Q20 bases: 574873704(91.5901%). Q30 bases: 519691393(82.7984%). Read2 before filtering:. total reads: 4184393. total bases: 627658950. Q20 bases: 610311658(97.2362%). Q30 bases: 586633038(93.4637%). Read1 after filtering:. total reads: 3973376. total bases: 595992914. Q20 bases: 557478530(93.5378%). Q30 bases: 509011747(85.4057%). Read2 after filtering:. total reads: 3973376. total bases: 595992914. Q20 bases: 581197206(97.5175%). Q30 bases: 559400719(93.8603%). [...]. ```. Thanks . Best regards

Read2 before filtering:. total reads: 4184393. total bases: 627658950. Q20 bases: 610311658(97.2362%). Q30 bases: 586633038(93.4637%). Read1 after filtering:. total reads: 3973376. total bases: 595992914. Q20 bases: 557478530(93.5378%). Q30 bases: 509011747(85.4057%). Read2 after filtering:. total reads: 3973376. total bases: 595992914. Q20 bases: 581197206(97.5175%). Q30 bases: 559400719(93.8603%). [...]. ```. Thanks . Best regards

sentence: UMI analysis with XT-HS library; Hello,. I use the SSEL XT-HS/Low Input kit from Agilent and the UMIs are positioned at index 2 (see picture below. ![Molecular_Barcode](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3015749/163394420-9c5461e0-29ed-43b0-be6d-867178690e30.png). ). The UMIs are in a separate FASTQ file. Is fastp able to handle this type of build and how do I set up the UMI file in the fastp command? Thank you.

sentence: Duplication rate reported differently in v20.1 compare to v23.1 ; Hi developer, . I am using Fastp to trim my dataset. When I used v20.1, the duplication rate was ~6.7%. However, with the same command, parameter and dataset, the duplication rate has increased to ~72%. The rest of the statistics are the same, except for the duplication rate. May I get your opinion on this? Attached is the output for your reference. Thanks. **Command used for both version:**. fastp -w 16 -q 20 -l 50 -a AAGTCGGAGGCCAAGCGGTCTTAGGAAGACAA -i S200034436_L01_103_1.fq.gz --adapter_sequence_r2. AAGTCGGATCGTAGCCATGTCGTTCTGTGAGCCAAGGAGTTG -I S200034436_L01_103_2.fq.gz -o trimmed_1.fq.gz -O trimmed_2.fq.gz --correction -R Redcliffe-QC-Report --html Raw_Data_QC_Report.html. **v20.1**. . **v23.1**. .
author: OpenGene

sentence: stdin/stdout error while pipe; Hi, . When I use the following command to check fastqs, however it returns the error. But without using pipe into fastp, it works well. . May I get your opinion on this? **fastp version[0.23.0]**. ```. gatk SamToFastq \. --CLIPPING_ATTRIBUTE XT --CLIPPING_ACTION 2 \. --FASTQ /dev/stdout --INTERLEAVE true -NON_PF true \. --TMP_DIR -I umi.ubam | \. fastp --stdin --interleaved_in \. --html my.html --json my.json -o fq1.gz -O fq2.gz. ```. And here is the error log:. ```. To get help, see http://broadinstitute.github.io/picard/index.html#GettingHelp. htsjdk.samtools.SAMException: Error in writing fastq file /dev/stdout. at htsjdk.samtools.fastq.BasicFastqWriter.checkError(BasicFastqWriter.java:69). at htsjdk.samtools.fastq.BasicFastqWriter.flush(BasicFastqWriter.java:75). at htsjdk.samtools.fastq.BasicFastqWriter.close(BasicFastqWriter.java:81). at htsjdk.samtools.fastq.AsyncFastqWriter.synchronouslyClose(AsyncFastqWriter.java:19). at htsjdk.samtools.util.AbstractAsyncWriter.close(AbstractAsyncWriter.java:89). at picard.sam.SamToFastq$FastqWriters.closeAll(SamToFastq.java:541). at picard.sam.SamToFastq$FastqWriters.access$000(SamToFastq.java:500). at picard.sam.SamToFastq.doWork(SamToFastq.java:214). at picard.cmdline.CommandLineProgram.instanceMain(CommandLineProgram.java:308). at org.broadinstitute.hellbender.cmdline.PicardCommandLineProgramExecutor.instanceMain(PicardCommandLineProgramExecutor.java:37). at org.broadinstitute.hellbender.Main.runCommandLineProgram(Main.java:160). at org.broadinstitute.hellbender.Main.mainEntry(Main.java:203). at org.broadinstitute.hellbender.Main.main(Main.java:289). Segmentation fault. ```. Best,. xiucz

author: OpenGene

sentence: nebnext single cell rna seq templete switching oligo and G and T homopolymers trimming.; Hi all,. Any recommendations on how to trim the generated fastq files from this library using fastP? The default options can not automatically recognize the adapters. The adapters used are described [HERE](https://international.neb.com/faqs/2018/04/19/how-should-the-adaptor-sequences-be-trimmed). In this page they recommend using [FlexBar](https://github.com/nebiolabs/nebnext-single-cell-rna-seq). Flexbar first will remove the switching oligo and also G and T homopolymers using the following options:. ```. Homopolymers adjacent to the template-switching oligo are trimmed as well, as specified by --htrim* options. G and T homopolymers are trimmed (--htrim-left GT --htrim-right CA). Homopolymer length to trim is 3-5 for G, and 3 or higher for T (--htrim-min-length 3 --htrim-max-length 5 --htrim-max-first). Keeping a short minimum read length after trimming (--min-read-length 2) keeps informative long reads, whose mates may be short after trimming. . ```. Then it will proceed on trimming the illumina adapters. I am unsure how this can be adjusted for fastp and also how can fastp handle those 2 steps. Thank you all in advance.

Keeping a short minimum read length after trimming (--min-read-length 2) keeps informative long reads, whose mates may be short after trimming. . ```. Then it will proceed on trimming the illumina adapters. I am unsure how this can be adjusted for fastp and also how can fastp handle those 2 steps. Thank you all in advance.

author: OpenGene

sentence: per read cutting by quality score - quality above 30; Hi @sfchen ! I would like to use fastp (v0.23.2) function --cut_tail in window size 4, but with the average quality set on 37. Fastp allows running this trimming with maximum average quality 30. Although a description (fastp -h) states that the quality range is 1-36. > -M, --cut_mean_quality the mean quality requirement option shared by cut_front, cut_tail or cut_sliding. Range: 1~36 default: 20 (Q20) (int [=20]). Is it possible to change this limitation in fastp? I know that in trimmomatic I can set up average quality above 30, but trimmomatic scan reads from 5'. I'm looking for a program which scan reads from 3' end like fastp. I appreciate your help. Best,. Arek

sentence: Installing newer versions with conda; Hello,. I attempted to install the newest fastp `version 0.23.2` using conda but I am facing compatibility issues:. ```UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be incompatible with each other:. Output in format: Requested package -> Available versions. Package libgcc-ng conflicts for:. fastp=0.23.2 -> libgcc-ng[version='>=10.3.0|>=9.4.0']. fastp=0.23.2 -> libdeflate[version='>=1.7,<1.8.0a0'] -> libgcc-ng[version='>=7.3.0']. Package _libgcc_mutex conflicts for:. fastp=0.23.2 -> libgcc-ng[version='>=10.3.0'] -> _libgcc_mutex==0.1=conda_forge. python=3.8.1 -> libgcc-ng[version='>=7.3.0'] -> _libgcc_mutex[version='*|0.1',build='conda_forge|main|main']The following specifications were found to be incompatible with your system:. - feature:/linux-64::__glibc==2.27=0. - feature:|@/linux-64::__glibc==2.27=0. - python=3.8.1 -> libgcc-ng[version='>=7.3.0'] -> __glibc[version='>=2.17']. Your installed version is: 2.27 . ```. I was wondering if you have a conda environment available that would resolve these issues. Additionally, I tried using `version 0.19.3`, and whenever I added `-y` for complexity filtering, I started getting `Segmentation Fault (core dumped)`. *Note:* This does not occur when not using complexity filtering. Thank you!

sentence: Feature Request: Option to save discarded reads (SE and PE) in a file; Hi,. Thank you for this great tool. It is possible to add options like -i_dis "discarded_read1_path.fastq" -I_dis "discarded_read2_path.fastq" to save all reads that are discarded in filtering steps (e.g. < quality average, etc)? Best regards
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: order of operations when PE merging/base correcting; Thanks so much for developing fastp! Wanted to double check something about PE merging and base correction (--merge, --correction). When in the order of operations does fastp check for overlaps? For example, do these steps occur before, after, in the middle of the items 1-11 listed in https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp#global-trimming? Edit: How about deduplication? Cheers!

sentence: Fastp does not show insert size peak; Dear developer,. I try to preprocess my fastq file using default parameter of Fastp, but the result did not show insert size peak. Why is that ? Feel free to let me know if I am missunderstanding (The result has been already attached as pdf of HTML file). [fastp_Truseq_primer2.pdf](https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/files/8866715/fastp_Truseq_primer2.pdf).
