author: OpenGene

sentence: Change order of trimming steps; Hello,. Thanks for actively developping fastp. . Is it possible to change the order of the trimming steps with fastp? I would need to trim adaptors and do the quality trimming before removing bases at the 3' or 5' end of the reads using trim_front and trim_tail. . The only workaround I have found is by doing it sequentially - first by removing adaptors and then by applying trim_front and trim_tail in a second run on the already adaptor-trimmed fastq. Thanks a lot,. Damien

author: OpenGene

sentence: Specifying a value greater than the number of available cores for the -w option; Thank you for developing this nice tool! This may not be a question specific to fastp, but what happens when I specify a value greater than the number of available cores for the -w (--thread) option? I found that I used only one core on the cluster for running fastp with default settings (i.e., -w 2 in older versions and -w 3 in the new version of fastp). However, I found that the job finished successfully even though the number of core (=1) was smaller than the number of threads specified by -w option. I suppose that fastp runs in a parallel mode if fastp can use a sufficient number of cores, but it runs in a concurrent mode if it cannot use enough cores. Is it the case? Thank you.
author: OpenGene

I suppose that fastp runs in a parallel mode if fastp can use a sufficient number of cores, but it runs in a concurrent mode if it cannot use enough cores. Is it the case? Thank you.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Specifying a value greater than the number of available cores for the -w option; Thank you for developing this nice tool! sentence: Adapter stringency settings?; Is there a way to modify the stringency/match settings for adapter detection and trimming? I have an adapter fasta from long read (HiFi) data and those adapters are present in the reads, but usually only partial fragment (e.g. 40 bp out of 45).

sentence: A serious adapter trim bug for targeted sequencing data? use cutadapt instead; In the following example, I want to remove polyA, the expected last several bases should be `CTTTT`. But using the latest (v0.23.2) `fastp -i test.fastq --adapter_sequence AAAAAAAAAA --stdout `, I will only have `CTTT`, with the last `T` missing. I think this is because TAAAAAAAAA matched to the given adapter sequence with only 1 mismatch. However, this won't be an issue for cutadapt, even though cutadapt also allow 10% error. `cutadapt -a AAAAAAAAAA test.fastq > out.fastq`. ```. more test.fastq. @M04990:162:000000000-GCHR8:1:1101:15420:1384 1:N:0:ATTCAGAA+ATAGAGGC. author: OpenGene

sentence: A serious adapter trim bug for targeted sequencing data? use cutadapt instead; In the following example, I want to remove polyA, the expected last several bases should be `CTTTT`. But using the latest (v0.23.2) `fastp -i test.fastq --adapter_sequence AAAAAAAAAA --stdout `, I will only have `CTTT`, with the last `T` missing. I think this is because TAAAAAAAAA matched to the given adapter sequence with only 1 mismatch. However, this won't be an issue for cutadapt, even though cutadapt also allow 10% error. `cutadapt -a AAAAAAAAAA test.fastq > out.fastq`. ```. more test.fastq. @M04990:162:000000000-GCHR8:1:1101:15420:1384 1:N:0:ATTCAGAA+ATAGAGGC. author: OpenGene

sentence: A serious adapter trim bug for targeted sequencing data? use cutadapt instead; In the following example, I want to remove polyA, the expected last several bases should be `CTTTT`. But using the latest (v0.23.2) `fastp -i test.fastq --adapter_sequence AAAAAAAAAA --stdout `, I will only have `CTTT`, with the last `T` missing. I think this is because TAAAAAAAAA matched to the given adapter sequence with only 1 mismatch. However, this won't be an issue for cutadapt, even though cutadapt also allow 10% error. `cutadapt -a AAAAAAAAAA test.fastq > out.fastq`. ```. more test.fastq. @M04990:162:000000000-GCHR8:1:1101:15420:1384 1:N:0:ATTCAGAA+ATAGAGGC. sentence: A serious adapter trim bug for targeted sequencing data? use cutadapt instead; In the following example, I want to remove polyA, the expected last several bases should be `CTTTT`. But using the latest (v0.23.2) `fastp -i test.fastq --adapter_sequence AAAAAAAAAA --stdout `, I will only have `CTTT`, with the last `T` missing. I think this is because TAAAAAAAAA matched to the given adapter sequence with only 1 mismatch. However, this won't be an issue for cutadapt, even though cutadapt also allow 10% error. `cutadapt -a AAAAAAAAAA test.fastq > out.fastq`. ```. more test.fastq. @M04990:162:000000000-GCHR8:1:1101:15420:1384 1:N:0:ATTCAGAA+ATAGAGGC. sentence: How to use the location of 2-4bp as UMI of reads at 5' ? ; Thanks for your great work。. I want to remove the begin 1 bp and use the 2-4 bp as UMI , did `fastp` support this? ```. fastp ... \. --trim_front1 1 --trim_front1 1 \. -U --umi_loc per_read --umi_prefix UMI --umi_len 3 --umi_skip 3 . ```. and it use the 1-3bp as UMI。
author: OpenGene

sentence: In overrepresented sequence analysis, it seems like it should be i<=len-step instead of <; Hi! I am using the latest fastp and I found in state.cpp:. ```. // do overrepresentation analysis for 1 of every 100 reads. if(mOptions->overRepAnalysis.enabled) {. if(mReads % mOptions->overRepAnalysis.sampling == 0) {. const int steps[5] = {10, 20, 40, 100, min(150, mEvaluatedSeqLen-2)};. for(int s=0; s<5; s++) {. int step = steps[s];. for(int i=0; i<len-step; i++) {. string seq = r->mSeq->substr(i, step);. if(mOverRepSeq.count(seq)>0) {. mOverRepSeq[seq]++;. for(int p = i; p < seq.length() + i && p < mEvaluatedSeqLen; p++) {. mOverRepSeqDist[seq][p]++;. }. i+=step;. }. }. }. }. }. ```. this line : `for(int i=0; i<len-step; i++)`, it seems like it should be `i<=len-step` instead of `<`. If it is `<`, it seems to cause the number of hotseqs found during preprocessing to be 0 at the end. Incidentally, why `i+=step`, is it because over-representation of sequences cannot have overlap? Thank you!
author: OpenGene

sentence: Running fastp - AWS AMI Scaling Groups; looking to see if anyone has insight as to the success or failure with running fastp on AWS Scaling groups using a FOR LOOP, python script for samples in folders to pickup files in AWS S3, to run, then shoot the -o to S3, then process the reports? Trying to build the automation of allowing fastp to run serverless.

sentence: Add option to set the delimiter between the read name and the UMI; This allows fastp to match the behaviour of UMI-Tools, which uses (and requires) an underscore between the read name and the UMI. e.g. ```bash. $ fastp -i R1.fq -o out.R1.fq --umi --umi_loc=read1 --umi_len=8 --umi_delim=_. ```. ```bash. $ head out.R1.fq. @AS500713:64:HFKJJBGXY:1:11101:17113:1101_TACAAAAT 1:A:0:TATAGCCT+GTTTCTTA. GCACATCGCTGAAAGGGGTAAAGGAGAGAAATCGCTTTATAAAACCTTGAAAAGGAATATTCAAATATAAGCTGGGAAGGTATAAAAAACTCTGTACATCACAAGTAAACAAATGGAACCTGCAAAATATTAAACAAAGGATT. +. EE6EEAAAEEEEE6EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEAEEEEAEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEECFE####EEEE6EE<AAEEEAEEEEEEEEEEEEAEEEEEEEA<E/AAEEEAEEEEE/EEEEAAEEE. @AS500713:64:HFKJJBGXY:1:11101:1675:1101_TAGGAGGC 1:A:0:TATAGCCT+GACCCCCA. TTGGAGTACCAATAATAAAGTGAGCCCACCTTCCTGGTACCCAGACATTTCAGGAGGTCGGGAAATTTTTAAACCCAGGCAGCTTCCTGGCAGTGACATTTGGAGCATCAAAGTGGTAAATAAAATTTCATTTACATTAATAT. +. EEE/E/EA/E/AEA6EE//AEE66/AAE//EEE/E//E/AA/EEE/A/AEE/EEA//EEEEEEEE6EEAAA/E###6E/6//6<EAAEEE/EEEA/EA/EEEEEE/<<EEEE//A/EE<AEEEEE/</AA</E<AAAE/E<E/. @AS500713:64:HFKJJBGXY:1:11101:17113:1101_TACAAAAT 1:A:0:TATAGCCT+GTTTCTTA. ```

author: OpenGene

sentence: ether you can input multiple R1 and R2 reads from the same sample over multiple lanes into fastp and output into one concatenated fastq.gz... Here is a basic script I used:. ```. `#script to trim illumina paired end reads with fastp. ipath=$1 #list of directories from illumina run. opath=$2 #output path. unique=$3 . #make sure opath exists without overwriting. mkdir -p $opath. #loop through directories for fastp . cd $ipath . for i in $(ls). do. 	mkdir -p ${opath}/${i}. 	fastp -i ${i}/*R1.fastq.gz -I ${i}/*R2.fastq.gz -o ${opath}/${i}/trimmed-${i}-${unique}-R1.fastq.gz -O ${opath}/${i}/trimmed-${i}-${unique}-R2.fastq.gz -j ${opath}/${i}/${i}-${unique}-fastp.json -h ${opath}/${i}/${i}-${unique}-fastp.html --thread 16 . done	. `. ```. in "i" I had multiple R1 and R2 files for one sample. However the output file size resembled the size of one fastq as opposed to 4. . It printed the command back to me as I expected:. `fastp -i Sample_102/102_220713_L001_R1.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220713_L002_R1.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220713_L003_R1.fastq.gz Sample_102/10z Sample_102/102_220729_L002_R1.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220729_L003_R1.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220729_L004_R1.fastq.gz -I Sample_102/102_220713_L001_R2.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220713_L002_R2.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220713_L003_R2.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220713_L004_R2.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220729_L001_R2.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220729_L002_R2.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220729_L003_R2.fastq.gz Sample_102/102_220729_L004_R2.fastq.gz -o /home/rebee/projects/DRAGON/data/Trimmed/Sample_102/trimmed-Sample_102-P2-R1.fastq.gz -O /home/rebee/projects/DRAGON/data/Trimmed/Sample_102/trimmed-Sample_102-P2-R2.fastq.gz -j /home/rebee/projects/DRAGON/data/Trimmed/Sample_102/Sample_102-P2-fastp.json -h /home/rebee/projects/DRAGON/data/Trimmed/Sample_102/Sample_102-P2-fastp.html --thread 16`. Is there a way for fastp to recognise multiple input for one sample? Or is it better practice to concatenate them first? Any thoughts welcome! . :)

author: OpenGene

sentence: Adapter mismatch ; Im trimming a 27 bp adaptor from SE data. There are too many adaptor mismatches in some reads, resulting in two sequence distribution lengths. I've tried using different adaptor lengths with '-a' but I cannot get a good trim of my data. Any suggestions? I was thinking of running two adapter trims, one trimming the beginning of the adaptor and the other trimming the end. Is that a safe option? I'm assuming there's no adjustable parameter for adapter mismatch.

sentence: fastp stalls when there are unequal number of reads in R1 and R2; Hi,. I know I'm doing unspeakable things with terrible input data but hear me out. We've had an issue in a production pipeline where some runs would stall and never finish. As it turns out, all samples that stall have different number of reads in the forward and reverse file, probably due to interrupted data transfer between us and our sequencing provider. In any case, I've done some testing, and `fastp` stalls when the difference is more than 500k reads between the forward and reverse file, corresponding to at least 500 "packs" of reads and, if I understand correctly, is the maximum limit of "packs" that fastp holds in memory. Right now we can implement a check before running `fastp`, but it would be nice if `fastp` would either finish its course, or crash when the difference is too big between forward and reverse files (or when any difference occurs, I'm happy with a pipeline crash that we can catch, we should reject these input samples anyway in our workflow). ### Output of a completed fastp verbose output:. this R2 subset has 486 less packs than R1. <details>. <summary>Completed</summary>. ``` . fastp -V -w 8 -q 20 -l 50 -3 -5 -M 20 -i DRR291616_1.fastq.gz -I DRR. _sub77_R2.fastq.gz -o 77_r1.fastq.gz -O 77_r2.fastq.gz. [10:31:44] start to load data of read1. [10:31:44] start to load data of read2. [10:31:45] Read1: loaded 1M reads. [10:31:45] Read2: loaded 1M reads. [10:31:46] Read2: loading completed with 1619 packs. [10:31:47] Read1: loaded 2M reads. [10:31:47] thread 5 data processing completed. [10:31:47] thread 5 finished. Right now we can implement a check before running `fastp`, but it would be nice if `fastp` would either finish its course, or crash when the difference is too big between forward and reverse files (or when any difference occurs, I'm happy with a pipeline crash that we can catch, we should reject these input samples anyway in our workflow). ### Output of a completed fastp verbose output:. this R2 subset has 486 less packs than R1. <details>. <summary>Completed</summary>. ``` . fastp -V -w 8 -q 20 -l 50 -3 -5 -M 20 -i DRR291616_1.fastq.gz -I DRR. _sub77_R2.fastq.gz -o 77_r1.fastq.gz -O 77_r2.fastq.gz. author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp stalls when there are unequal number of reads in R1 and R2; Hi,. I know I'm doing unspeakable things with terrible input data but hear me out. We've had an issue in a production pipeline where some runs would stall and never finish. As it turns out, all samples that stall have different number of reads in the forward and reverse file, probably due to interrupted data transfer between us and our sequencing provider. In any case, I've done some testing, and `fastp` stalls when the difference is more than 500k reads between the forward and reverse file, corresponding to at least 500 "packs" of reads and, if I understand correctly, is the maximum limit of "packs" that fastp holds in memory. Right now we can implement a check before running `fastp`, but it would be nice if `fastp` would either finish its course, or crash when the difference is too big between forward and reverse files (or when any difference occurs, I'm happy with a pipeline crash that we can catch, we should reject these input samples anyway in our workflow). ### Output of a completed fastp verbose output:. this R2 subset has 486 less packs than R1. <details>. <summary>Completed</summary>. ``` . fastp -V -w 8 -q 20 -l 50 -3 -5 -M 20 -i DRR291616_1.fastq.gz -I DRR. _sub77_R2.fastq.gz -o 77_r1.fastq.gz -O 77_r2.fastq.gz. sentence: fastp stalls when there are unequal number of reads in R1 and R2; Hi,. I know I'm doing unspeakable things with terrible input data but hear me out. We've had an issue in a production pipeline where some runs would stall and never finish. As it turns out, all samples that stall have different number of reads in the forward and reverse file, probably due to interrupted data transfer between us and our sequencing provider. In any case, I've done some testing, and `fastp` stalls when the difference is more than 500k reads between the forward and reverse file, corresponding to at least 500 "packs" of reads and, if I understand correctly, is the maximum limit of "packs" that fastp holds in memory. Right now we can implement a check before running `fastp`, but it would be nice if `fastp` would either finish its course, or crash when the difference is too big between forward and reverse files (or when any difference occurs, I'm happy with a pipeline crash that we can catch, we should reject these input samples anyway in our workflow). ### Output of a completed fastp verbose output:. this R2 subset has 486 less packs than R1. <details>. <summary>Completed</summary>. ``` . fastp -V -w 8 -q 20 -l 50 -3 -5 -M 20 -i DRR291616_1.fastq.gz -I DRR. _sub77_R2.fastq.gz -o 77_r1.fastq.gz -O 77_r2.fastq.gz. author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp stalls when there are unequal number of reads in R1 and R2; Hi,. I know I'm doing unspeakable things with terrible input data but hear me out. We've had an issue in a production pipeline where some runs would stall and never finish. As it turns out, all samples that stall have different number of reads in the forward and reverse file, probably due to interrupted data transfer between us and our sequencing provider. In any case, I've done some testing, and `fastp` stalls when the difference is more than 500k reads between the forward and reverse file, corresponding to at least 500 "packs" of reads and, if I understand correctly, is the maximum limit of "packs" that fastp holds in memory. Right now we can implement a check before running `fastp`, but it would be nice if `fastp` would either finish its course, or crash when the difference is too big between forward and reverse files (or when any difference occurs, I'm happy with a pipeline crash that we can catch, we should reject these input samples anyway in our workflow). ### Output of a completed fastp verbose output:. this R2 subset has 486 less packs than R1. <details>. <summary>Completed</summary>. ``` . fastp -V -w 8 -q 20 -l 50 -3 -5 -M 20 -i DRR291616_1.fastq.gz -I DRR. _sub77_R2.fastq.gz -o 77_r1.fastq.gz -O 77_r2.fastq.gz. sentence: cing provider. In any case, I've done some testing, and `fastp` stalls when the difference is more than 500k reads between the forward and reverse file, corresponding to at least 500 "packs" of reads and, if I understand correctly, is the maximum limit of "packs" that fastp holds in memory. Right now we can implement a check before running `fastp`, but it would be nice if `fastp` would either finish its course, or crash when the difference is too big between forward and reverse files (or when any difference occurs, I'm happy with a pipeline crash that we can catch, we should reject these input samples anyway in our workflow). ### Output of a completed fastp verbose output:. this R2 subset has 486 less packs than R1. <details>. <summary>Completed</summary>. ``` . fastp -V -w 8 -q 20 -l 50 -3 -5 -M 20 -i DRR291616_1.fastq.gz -I DRR. _sub77_R2.fastq.gz -o 77_r1.fastq.gz -O 77_r2.fastq.gz. author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp stalls when there are unequal number of reads in R1 and R2; Hi,. I know I'm doing unspeakable things with terrible input data but hear me out. We've had an issue in a production pipeline where some runs would stall and never finish. As it turns out, all samples that stall have different number of reads in the forward and reverse file, probably due to interrupted data transfer between us and our sequencing provider. In any case, I've done some testing, and `fastp` stalls when the difference is more than 500k reads between the forward and reverse file, corresponding to at least 500 "packs" of reads and, if I understand correctly, is the maximum limit of "packs" that fastp holds in memory. Right now we can implement a check before running `fastp`, but it would be nice if `fastp` would either finish its course, or crash when the difference is too big between forward and reverse files (or when any difference occurs, I'm happy with a pipeline crash that we can catch, we should reject these input samples anyway in our workflow). ### Output of a completed fastp verbose output:. this R2 subset has 486 less packs than R1. <details>. <summary>Completed</summary>. ``` . fastp -V -w 8 -q 20 -l 50 -3 -5 -M 20 -i DRR291616_1.fastq.gz -I DRR. _sub77_R2.fastq.gz -o 77_r1.fastq.gz -O 77_r2.fastq.gz. author: OpenGene

sentence: Hi,. I know I'm doing unspeakable things with terrible input data but hear me out. We've had an issue in a production pipeline where some runs would stall and never finish. As it turns out, all samples that stall have different number of reads in the forward and reverse file, probably due to interrupted data transfer between us and our sequencing provider. In any case, I've done some testing, and `fastp` stalls when the difference is more than 500k reads between the forward and reverse file, corresponding to at least 500 "packs" of reads and, if I understand correctly, is the maximum limit of "packs" that fastp holds in memory. Right now we can implement a check before running `fastp`, but it would be nice if `fastp` would either finish its course, or crash when the difference is too big between forward and reverse files (or when any difference occurs, I'm happy with a pipeline crash that we can catch, we should reject these input samples anyway in our workflow). ### Output of a completed fastp verbose output:. this R2 subset has 486 less packs than R1. <details>. <summary>Completed</summary>. ``` . fastp -V -w 8 -q 20 -l 50 -3 -5 -M 20 -i DRR291616_1.fastq.gz -I DRR. _sub77_R2.fastq.gz -o 77_r1.fastq.gz -O 77_r2.fastq.gz. [10:31:44] start to load data of read1. [10:31:44] start to load data of read2. [10:31:45] Read1: loaded 1M reads. [10:31:45] Read2: loaded 1M reads. [10:31:46] Read2: loading completed with 1619 packs. [10:31:47] Read1: loaded 2M reads. [10:31:47] thread 5 data processing completed. [10:31:47] thread 5 finished. author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp stalls when there are unequal number of reads in R1 and R2; Hi,. I know I'm doing unspeakable things with terrible input data but hear me out. We've had an issue in a production pipeline where some runs would stall and never finish. As it turns out, all samples that stall have different number of reads in the forward and reverse file, probably due to interrupted data transfer between us and our sequencing provider. In any case, I've done some testing, and `fastp` stalls when the difference is more than 500k reads between the forward and reverse file, corresponding to at least 500 "packs" of reads and, if I understand correctly, is the maximum limit of "packs" that fastp holds in memory. Right now we can implement a check before running `fastp`, but it would be nice if `fastp` would either finish its course, or crash when the difference is too big between forward and reverse files (or when any difference occurs, I'm happy with a pipeline crash that we can catch, we should reject these input samples anyway in our workflow). ### Output of a completed fastp verbose output:. this R2 subset has 486 less packs than R1. <details>. <summary>Completed</summary>. ``` . fastp -V -w 8 -q 20 -l 50 -3 -5 -M 20 -i DRR291616_1.fastq.gz -I DRR. _sub77_R2.fastq.gz -o 77_r1.fastq.gz -O 77_r2.fastq.gz. [10:31:44] start to load data of read1. [10:31:44] start to load data of read2. [10:31:45] Read1: loaded 1M reads. [10:31:45] Read2: loaded 1M reads. [10:31:46] Read2: loading completed with 1619 packs. [10:31:47] Read1: loaded 2M reads. [10:31:47] thread 5 data processing completed. [10:31:47] thread 5 finished. author: OpenGene

sentence: Bug when deal with phred 64 reads; Hi,. I found if I use fastp to process phred 64 reads (with `-6`), if the data amount is large (such as >20,000 reads, haven't tested the exact number),. 1. fastp cannot correct calculate the Q20/Q30 base and the quality_curves is still >60 (haven't changed it to phred 33 to show). 2. the result cannot be repeated (the results were slightly different each time with the same parameters). . However, if the data amount is small (say <15000), everything is fine. . This situation only happens in the version > 0.20.0. In v 0.20.0, everything is fine (both the read quality and result between different runs). . I am not sure whether it is related the speed up after 0.20.0? Many thanks,. Raymond

sentence: Bug when deal with phred 64 reads; Hi,. I found if I use fastp to process phred 64 reads (with `-6`), if the data amount is large (such as >20,000 reads, haven't tested the exact number),. 1. fastp cannot correct calculate the Q20/Q30 base and the quality_curves is still >60 (haven't changed it to phred 33 to show). 2. the result cannot be repeated (the results were slightly different each time with the same parameters). . However, if the data amount is small (say <15000), everything is fine. . This situation only happens in the version > 0.20.0. In v 0.20.0, everything is fine (both the read quality and result between different runs). . I am not sure whether it is related the speed up after 0.20.0? Many thanks,. Raymond

sentence: How to tell if fastp stopped prematurely?; Hello,. Thank you for the great tool! I was wondering, is there a way to tell if fastp stopped running prematurely? If I cancel the command before it finishes running, log files are still generated that provide a summary of the filtering. Is there any information in the log files that can be used to tell if filtering was performed on all reads or if it ended early due to an interruption? Thank you again!

sentence: -l option does not filter out all reads below the required read length; Hi,. I am currently using fastp to perform some quality inspection and refinement on some of my fastq files. One of the issues of my fastq files is that although samples were sent for sequencing with 150 bp read length, there are still some reads shorter than 150 bp within the fastq files. Therefore I set the `-l` option to 150 while running fastp on my fastq files hoping to remove all reads that are shorter than 150 bp. However, it turns out the `-l 150` option only partially removes the reads shorter than 150 bp within my fastq files, as shown by the read length counts summary of the same fastq file before and after the fastp filtering (provided by fastqc): . **before filtering:**. . **after filtering:** . . For the reference, this is the command I ran to to perform fastp filtering on this sample:. `/home/jis215/anaconda3/bin/fastp --thread 4 -l 150 -i /home/jis215/Aicardi_mosaic/1-Realignment/merged_fastq/8289-2-bl_R1.fastq.gz -I /home/jis215/Aicardi_mosaic/1-Realignment/merged_fastq/8289-2-bl_R2.fastq.gz -o /projects/ps-. gleesonlab8/Uniformly_processed_data/20220809_jis215_Aicardi_UCSF_WGS_Re-analysis/1-Realignment/fastp_filtered_fastq/8289-2-bl_filtered_R1.fastq.gz -O /projects/ps-gleesonlab8/Uniformly_processed_data/20220809_jis215_Aicardi_UCSF_WGS_Re-analysis/1. -Realignment/fastp_filtered_fastq/8289-2-bl_filtered_R2.fastq.gz -h /projects/ps-gleesonlab8/Uniformly_processed_data/20220809_jis215_Aicardi_UCSF_WGS_Re-analysis/1-Realignment/fastp_filtered_fastq/report/8289-2-bl_fastp.html -j /projects/ps-glees. onlab8/Uniformly_processed_data/20220809_jis215_Aicardi_

sentence: -l option does not filter out all reads below the required read length; Hi,. I am currently using fastp to perform some quality inspection and refinement on some of my fastq files. One of the issues of my fastq files is that although samples were sent for sequencing with 150 bp read length, there are still some reads shorter than 150 bp within the fastq files. Therefore I set the `-l` option to 150 while running fastp on my fastq files hoping to remove all reads that are shorter than 150 bp. However, it turns out the `-l 150` option only partially removes the reads shorter than 150 bp within my fastq files, as shown by the read length counts summary of the same fastq file before and after the fastp filtering (provided by fastqc): . **before filtering:**. . **after filtering:** . . For the reference, this is the command I ran to to perform fastp filtering on this sample:. `/home/jis215/anaconda3/bin/fastp --thread 4 -l 150 -i /home/jis215/Aicardi_mosaic/1-Realignment/merged_fastq/8289-2-bl_R1.fastq.gz -I /home/jis215/Aicardi_mosaic/1-Realignment/merged_fastq/8289-2-bl_R2.fastq.gz -o /projects/ps-. gleesonlab8/Uniformly_processed_data/20220809_jis215_Aicardi_UCSF_WGS_Re-analysis/1-Realignment/fastp_filtered_fastq/8289-2-bl_filtered_R1.fastq.gz -O /projects/ps-gleesonlab8/Uniformly_processed_data/20220809_jis215_Aicardi_UCSF_WGS_Re-analysis/1. -Realignment/fastp_filtered_fastq/8289-2-bl_filtered_R2.fastq.gz -h /projects/ps-gleesonlab8/Uniformly_processed_data/20220809_jis215_Aicardi_UCSF_WGS_Re-analysis/1-Realignment/fastp_filtered_fastq/report/8289-2-bl_fastp.html -j /projects/ps-glees. onlab8/Uniformly_processed_data/20220809_jis215_Aicardi_

sentence: Splitting paired fastq files; Hi, when using fastp to split paired fastq files and then input to bwa mem, one gets the error: "[mem_sam_pe] paired reads have different names". Does fastp have the ability to split paired fastq files in an even manner (similar to fastq splitter), or does the splitting 'scramble' the fastq file, no longer preserving read pairs?

sentence: umi sequence not removed from the other read.; Hi. I am using `fastp --umi` with the following commands. ```. fastp -i {input.fq1} -I {input.fq2} \. -o {output.fq1} -O {output.fq2} \. --disable_adapter_trimming \. --umi \. --umi_len={params.umi_length} \. --umi_loc=read1 \. --trim_poly_g \. -j {output.metrics} \. -h {output.metrics2} \. -w {params.cores}. ```. our sequencing is paired end, UMI is the first 10 bp in read1. **i found instances when the insert is short, the UMI is not removed from the other read (that reads into the UMI):** causing bad mapping. . in particular:. . read name after fastp: GCAAACTTAT is UMI. ```. 'A00475:502:HJLHHDRX2:1:2102:22842:9674:**GCAAACTTAT**1:N:0:ATTACTCG+AGGATAGGrbc:'. . read 1 after umi extraction. TAAGGTTTGCAAATTAAAAAGGGCCAGAAAC. read 2 after umi extraction:. GTTTCTGGCCCTTTTTAATTTGCAAACCTTAATAAGTTTGCAG. reverse complement of read 2. CTGCAAACTTATTAAGGTTTGCAAATTAAAAAGGGCCAGAAAC. ```. putting altogether:. read2 reverse: CT_GCAAACTTAT_**TAAGGTTTGCAAATTAAAAAGGGCCAGAAAC** (Bold is the same as read1, underscore is UMI). read1 : TAAGGTTTGCAAATTAAAAAGGGCCAGAAAC. UMI : GCAAACTTAT (underscore).
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: umi sequence not removed from the other read.; Hi. I am using `fastp --umi` with the following commands. ```. fastp -i {input.fq1} -I {input.fq2} \. -o {output.fq1} -O {output.fq2} \. --disable_adapter_trimming \. --umi \. --umi_len={params.umi_length} \. --umi_loc=read1 \. --trim_poly_g \. -j {output.metrics} \. -h {output.metrics2} \. -w {params.cores}. ```. our sequencing is paired end, UMI is the first 10 bp in read1. **i found instances when the insert is short, the UMI is not removed from the other read (that reads into the UMI):** causing bad mapping. . in particular:. . read name after fastp: GCAAACTTAT is UMI. ```. 'A00475:502:HJLHHDRX2:1:2102:22842:9674:**GCAAACTTAT**1:N:0:ATTACTCG+AGGATAGGrbc:'. . read 1 after umi extraction. TAAGGTTTGCAAATTAAAAAGGGCCAGAAAC. read 2 after umi extraction:. GTTTCTGGCCCTTTTTAATTTGCAAACCTTAATAAGTTTGCAG. reverse complement of read 2. CTGCAAACTTATTAAGGTTTGCAAATTAAAAAGGGCCAGAAAC. ```. putting altogether:. read2 reverse: CT_GCAAACTTAT_**TAAGGTTTGCAAATTAAAAAGGGCCAGAAAC** (Bold is the same as read1, underscore is UMI). read1 : TAAGGTTTGCAAATTAAAAAGGGCCAGAAAC. UMI : GCAAACTTAT (underscore).

(base) user@Ubuntu:~/fastp$ make. g++ -c src/stats.cpp -o obj/stats.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/htmlreporter.cpp -o obj/htmlreporter.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/writerthread.cpp -o obj/writerthread.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/sequence.cpp -o obj/sequence.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/basecorrector.cpp -o obj/basecorrector.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/unittest.cpp -o obj/unittest.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/threadconfig.cpp -o obj/threadconfig.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/filterresult.cpp -o obj/filterresult.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/readpool.cpp -o obj/readpool.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/fastareader.cpp -o obj/fastareader.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/read.cpp -o obj/read.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/overlapanalysis.cpp -o obj/overlapanalysis.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/processor.cpp -o obj/processor.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/polyx.cpp -o obj/polyx.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/umiprocessor.cpp -o obj/umiprocessor.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/peprocessor.cpp -o obj/peprocessor.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/duplicate.cpp -o obj/duplicate.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/adaptertrimmer.cpp -o obj/adaptertrimmer.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/nucleotidetree.cpp -o obj/nucleotidetree.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/seprocessor.cpp -o obj/seprocessor.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g++ -c src/evaluator.cpp -o obj/evaluator.o -std=c++11 -pthread -g -O3 -I./inc . g

sentence: Duplication rate histogram missing since v0.22.0; Thanks a lot for this extremely useful tool. It seems that since v0.22.0 the duplication rate histogram is not calculated anymore. That could be related to the deduplication feature added in that version but I cannot find it documented. Was that change intended? Would it be possible to have the histogram back? Thanks again.

sentence: Request to add QIAseq miRNA to known adapters; The QIAseq miRNA NGS 3’ Adapter is not included in the list of known adapters. It would be great to use `fastp` on miRNA data without having to manually specify adapter sequence. . The QIAseq miRNA adapter sequence is:. ```. AACTGTAGGCACCATCAAT. ```. Documentation: https://www.qiagen.com/kr/resources/faq?id=f12b85b4-df4f-43b5-9e82-a4fd0ddbdcc0&lang=en

sentence: can't improve the trimming; Hello,. I am using fastp to clean my data with the following options : . `fastp -w 18 -3 -5 -f 11 -F 3 -g --poly_g_min_len 5 --trim_poly_x --poly_x_min_len 5 -c -D 3 -y 5 --detect_adapter_for_pe --overrepresentation_analysis --correction --html `. I successfully removed the first 11 bp in my sequences but the last 3 bp (that make my Per Base Sequence content in fastqc fail) don't trim... although I specified -F 3 . how can I overcome this issue ? other question : the % of duplicated sequences still high even with -D option. should I run another tool to decrease it ? . Thank you. .
author: OpenGene

sentence: Deduplication before adapter trimming; Hi, I have a question regarding the possibility of running the deduplication before all the other steps. . I have a dataset in which each adapter possess a UMI sequence. Thus, each insert possess different UMI combinations. I want to use this information to perform better deduplication but I loose it if I trim off the adapters. . Can this be done disabling all the others functions and enabling deduplication? Something like:. **fastp -i 1.fastq.gz -I 2.fastq.gz -o 1.deduplicated.fastq.gz -O 2.deduplicated.fastq.gz -Q -L -A -D -h .html -j .json. done**. Or I would need to extract the UMI sequences from the adapters using the -U flag and perform deduplication after? Thanks in advance for the response!

sentence: option to remove appended merged_xxx_yyy when merging paired end reads; Hi there. Many thanks for this tool. I have been using it to merge PE reads for ribosome profiling, as the pipeline I'm using doesn't handle paired end reads very well. However, one of the downstream steps in this pipeline involves deduplication, using UMItools to remove PCR duplicates. For single end reads this is working fine for me, but for the fastq files containing merged paired end reads it is throwing an error, which I think is down to the appending of merged_xxx_yyy to the header lines of the merged fastq reads. Is there an option to stop fastp appending this? Many thanks. Joe
author: OpenGene

For single end reads this is working fine for me, but for the fastq files containing merged paired end reads it is throwing an error, which I think is down to the appending of merged_xxx_yyy to the header lines of the merged fastq reads. Is there an option to stop fastp appending this? Many thanks. Joe

author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp: filter data from different sequencing platform; Hi,. I will filter the raw data from multiple sequencing platforms, including 454 GS Junior, Illumina HiSeq 2000/2500/3000/4000, Illumina HiSeq X Ten, Illumina NextSeq 500, Illumina NovaSeq 6000, MGISEQ-2000RS, and PacBio RS II. . Could fastp be used to filter the raw sequencing data from the above platforms ??? If fastp could be used to treat all of these data, should I specify the platform by an option (I did not found relevant option in README.md) or the sequencing platform will be automatically detected for data in fastp?? Thank you.

sentence: fastp unable to detect adapter whereas fastqc can; Download dataset using SRA toolkit (version 3.0.0). `fastq-dump --split-spot --skip-technical --split-files --split-3 SRR12540267`. Run fastp (version 0.23.1). ```. fastp -i SRR12540267.fastq -o SRR12540267.fastq_fastp.fastq. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Read1 before filtering:. total reads: 40798612. total bases: 2692708392. Q20 bases: 2672862801(99.263%). Q30 bases: 2631719249(97.735%). Read1 after filtering:. total reads: 40783287. total bases: 2691696942. Q20 bases: 2672271597(99.2783%). Q30 bases: 2631312175(97.7566%). Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 40783287. reads failed due to low quality: 13195. reads failed due to too many N: 2130. reads failed due to too short: 0. reads with adapter trimmed: 0. bases trimmed due to adapters: 0. Duplication rate (may be overestimated since this is SE data): 56.2376%. JSON report: fastp.json. HTML report: fastp.html. fastp -i SRR12540267.fastq -o SRR12540267.fastq_fastp.fastq. fastp v0.23.1, time used: 62 seconds. ```. Run fastqc (version 0.11.9). `fastqc --nogroup -o QC SRR12540267.fastq`. . It looks like the majority of reads contain a segment of the adapter from nucleotides 43 to 66 (the sequence length reported by fastqc) based on the graph above. Therefore, unless I'm misunderstanding, fastp should not have an issue detecting the adapters even by samples the first many reads from the fastq file. Thank you for your assistance!

author: OpenGene

sentence: Failed to open file; Hi! Many thanks for this tool. I used `fastp` like this. ```. > cat test | while read id. > do. > name=`echo $id |awk '{print $1}'`. > read1=`echo $id |awk '{print $2}'`. > read2=`echo $id |awk '{print $3}'`. > echo $name . > echo $read1 . > echo $read2. > fastp \. > -i $read1 \. > -o ./test_R1.fq \. > -I $read2 \. > -O ./test_R2.fq. > done. ```. The test file is a txt file separate with \t. ![](https://img-1300058213.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/20221125153950.png). Then I got a error. ![](https://img-1300058213.cos.ap-shanghai.myqcloud.com/20221125154054.png). But when I use `fastp` direct. ```. fastp -i /home/imp008/private_hx_176/W034803N_HTW7JDSXX-L1_R1.fastq.gz -I /home/imp008/private_hx_176/W034803N_HTW7JDSXX-L1_R2.fastq.gz -o ./test_R1.fq -O ./test_R2.fq. ```. It works! So can you tell me why it can not open the R2 file? Thanks!!

author: OpenGene

sentence: Feature request: extraction of UMIs of variable lengths or based on sequence patterns or regular expressions; Hello. We are long-time users of fastp, and now are planning to incorporate UMIs in our experimental designs. I am wondering if there would be a possibility to allow extraction of UMIs based on sequence patterns or complex regular expression. I am thinking in particular about cases where the UMI is followed by a determined sequence common to all reads. ```. nnn[...]nnnXXXXXXXXXXrrrrrrrrrrrrr..... where . n=UMI nucleotides, variable length. X=determined sequence common to all reads. r=genomic insert of interest. ```. Having the possibility to extract the UMI as the sequence preceding the XXXXX sequence would be very interesting. Also, it would allow to extract UMIs of variable lengths, which is used in some sequencing applications. This is something that umi_tools allows, but I feel that in general fastp performs MUCH faster. Also I like the html reports. Having the possibility to stick to fastp not only for trimming but also to extract UMIs in more complex scenarios like this would be fantastic. Is this feasible? Thanks. Alex.

sentence: Feature request: extraction of UMIs of variable lengths or based on sequence patterns or regular expressions; Hello. We are long-time users of fastp, and now are planning to incorporate UMIs in our experimental designs. I am wondering if there would be a possibility to allow extraction of UMIs based on sequence patterns or complex regular expression. I am thinking in particular about cases where the UMI is followed by a determined sequence common to all reads. ```. nnn[...]nnnXXXXXXXXXXrrrrrrrrrrrrr..... where . n=UMI nucleotides, variable length. X=determined sequence common to all reads. r=genomic insert of interest. ```. Having the possibility to extract the UMI as the sequence preceding the XXXXX sequence would be very interesting. Also, it would allow to extract UMIs of variable lengths, which is used in some sequencing applications. This is something that umi_tools allows, but I feel that in general fastp performs MUCH faster. Also I like the html reports. Having the possibility to stick to fastp not only for trimming but also to extract UMIs in more complex scenarios like this would be fantastic. Is this feasible? Thanks. Alex.

sentence: fastp job was paused; Hi, fastp is very fast for fq clean. However, sometimes it will be paused for no reason and stop running for days. When I submit 100 jobs for WGS data clean, about 40 jobs were paused [the job is running normally but nothing was printed]. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41883635/204468409-edd5425c-4263-4fa8-ab69-afa4b55e30e5.png). here is my code. ls -1 *.fq.gz|parallel --max-args 2 -j 4 "fastp -S 400000000 -q 20 -u 10 -n 5 --in1 {1} --in2 {2} --out1 {1/} --out2 {2/} 2> {1/}.stat"
author: OpenGene

sentence: Algorithm for insert size estimation (1-30bp); Thank you for developing FastP. What's the algorithm for the insert size estimation? Why is it limited to insert size > 30bp? Have you benchmarked the insert size estimation, though I didn't find in the paper results (https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/bty560).
author: OpenGene

sentence: Algorithm for insert size estimation (1-30bp); Thank you for developing FastP. What's the algorithm for the insert size estimation? Why is it limited to insert size > 30bp? Have you benchmarked the insert size estimation, though I didn't find in the paper results (https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/bty560).
author: OpenGene

sentence: Extracting umi causes bwa to fail to recognize PE fastq; I try to run fasp to cut umi . ```. fastp -U --umi_loc per_read --umi_len 4 --umi_skip 2 ... celan.R1.fq.gz ... celan.R2.fq.gz. ```. then i run bwa ,but it return erro. ```. paired reads have different names: "F350009138L1C001R00300001098/1:TGAC_GAAC", "F350009138L1C001R00300001098/2:TGAC_GAAC". ```. I try to change sequence name ,replace ':' to ' '. ```. seqkit replace -p ":" -r ' ' clean.R1.fq.gz -o rn_clean_R1.fq.gz. ...... ```. finaly,bwa work. i think it is not a good to consume extra time to run seqkit。. Do you have a better plan？
author: OpenGene

sentence: Can set -j or -h function to be disabled?; Hi，fastp is a convenient and versatile tool for fastq quality control. But the -j or -h function seems can not be swtiched off, and sometimes this causes some trouble. . When I do batch jobs using fastp, and I only want to report json files, so I only set -j parameter . But the fastp will always output an additional html file which is generated from the last file to be processed in my batch job. . I am confused becasue when I set both -j and -h parameters, the above situation will not happen. So I think this situation may be caused by -j and -h function are enabled by default. . Can I set -j or -h function to be disabled?
author: OpenGene

sentence: ERROR: trim_front1 (--trim_front1) should be 0 ~ 30, suggest 0 ~ 4; Dear fastp developers:. I have 150-bp-length fastq reads, and I want to keep the 129~149th bases of each read, so I set "-f 129 -t 1" in fastp running. But I got the error as the title says. Sorry I do not understand this restriction. Would you please make a fix of this, thank you very much.

sentence: Fastp failing to detect adapters automatically; For sme unknown reason, Fastp is failing to detect Universal adapters in sequence. Given wide popularity of this tool in nextflow workflows these days, this is urgent to address. I have PE Iseq data and I ran FastP in three different ways:. **First**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json. ```. **Second**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --detect_adapter_for_pe --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json . ```. **Third**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --detect_adapter_for_pe --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json --adapter_fasta adapter.fasta . fastp v0.23.2. ```. The First two commands failed to trim the adapter sequences. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55479480/211192129-0e11db72-656c-42e9-b209-29992b6e2f1b.png). The Third one finally removed the adapters when provided with adapters fasta obtained from Trimmomatic. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55479480/211192215-92549af5-2fe5-4137-8e36-9bc17fe9b2c7.png).
author: OpenGene

I have PE Iseq data and I ran FastP in three different ways:. **First**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json. ```. **Second**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --detect_adapter_for_pe --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json . ```. **Third**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --detect_adapter_for_pe --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json --adapter_fasta adapter.fasta . fastp v0.23.2. ```. The First two commands failed to trim the adapter sequences. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55479480/211192129-0e11db72-656c-42e9-b209-29992b6e2f1b.png). The Third one finally removed the adapters when provided with adapters fasta obtained from Trimmomatic. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55479480/211192215-92549af5-2fe5-4137-8e36-9bc17fe9b2c7.png).

I have PE Iseq data and I ran FastP in three different ways:. **First**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json. ```. **Second**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --detect_adapter_for_pe --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json . ```. **Third**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --detect_adapter_for_pe --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json --adapter_fasta adapter.fasta . fastp v0.23.2. ```. The First two commands failed to trim the adapter sequences. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55479480/211192129-0e11db72-656c-42e9-b209-29992b6e2f1b.png). The Third one finally removed the adapters when provided with adapters fasta obtained from Trimmomatic. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55479480/211192215-92549af5-2fe5-4137-8e36-9bc17fe9b2c7.png).

I have PE Iseq data and I ran FastP in three different ways:. **First**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json. ```. **Second**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --detect_adapter_for_pe --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json . ```. **Third**. ```. fastp --in1 Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_001.fastq.gz --in2 Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_001.fastq.gz --out1 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R1_P.fastq.gz --out2 trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_R2_P.fastq.gz --html trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.html --detect_adapter_for_pe --json trim/Undetermined_S0_L001_.fastp_stats.json --adapter_fasta adapter.fasta . fastp v0.23.2. ```. The First two commands failed to trim the adapter sequences. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55479480/211192129-0e11db72-656c-42e9-b209-29992b6e2f1b.png). The Third one finally removed the adapters when provided with adapters fasta obtained from Trimmomatic. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/55479480/211192215-92549af5-2fe5-4137-8e36-9bc17fe9b2c7.png).

sentence: v0.23.2 hanging/deadlocked using Mac Ventura and Montery; . . Hello,. I am running a bash script for 136X paired end RNA fastq files (74bp) . Each pair's command uses the parameters: Nextera Adapter Sequence, trim_poly_g, trim_poly_x, average_qual, length_required, low complexity and correction. (see screenshot w/ purple terminal) In total there are 136 command instances. I have tried using 8 and 16 threads in both Ventura and Montery OS and fastp hangs/deadlocks after the 83rd fastq pair. I recognize the hanging deadlock because the last write-out was 3 minutes in the past instead (time was 0925 in screenshot, last write out was 0923 w/ black terminal) of 43-74 seconds later (using 8 threads). There is no error, the output hangs/deadlocks instead of moving onto the next command instances in the bash script. I have tried starting the bash script where the previous hang/deadlock occurred and it does not hang on the command it had previously been hung on and completes. Is there any solution other than breaking up my bash script?
author: OpenGene

Each pair's command uses the parameters: Nextera Adapter Sequence, trim_poly_g, trim_poly_x, average_qual, length_required, low complexity and correction. (see screenshot w/ purple terminal) In total there are 136 command instances. I have tried using 8 and 16 threads in both Ventura and Montery OS and fastp hangs/deadlocks after the 83rd fastq pair. I recognize the hanging deadlock because the last write-out was 3 minutes in the past instead (time was 0925 in screenshot, last write out was 0923 w/ black terminal) of 43-74 seconds later (using 8 threads). There is no error, the output hangs/deadlocks instead of moving onto the next command instances in the bash script. I have tried starting the bash script where the previous hang/deadlock occurred and it does not hang on the command it had previously been hung on and completes. Is there any solution other than breaking up my bash script?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Fastp quality scores plot shows naive means of phred scores not actual means; [Phred quality scores](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phred_quality_score) are log scores. A quality of 30 stands for a 1 in 1000 error rate. A quality of 10 stands for a 1 in 10 error rate. The average of 10 and 30 is therefore -10 * log10((0.1 + 0.001) /2) ~= 13. Not (10 + 30) / 2 = 20. On actual realworld data the average quality between the naive method and the proper can differ more than 10 Phred units. That is an overestimation of the quality by a factor of 10! . In the file I investigated, fastp reports the last cycles to have on average quality 34, while analysing it with a correct algorithm yields 22. The latter value is closer to 1 error per 100 which seems much more realistic than the less than 1 error per 1000 quality that fastp reports.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Fastp quality scores plot shows naive means of phred scores not actual means; [Phred quality scores](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phred_quality_score) are log scores. A quality of 30 stands for a 1 in 1000 error rate. A quality of 10 stands for a 1 in 10 error rate. The average of 10 and 30 is therefore -10 * log10((0.1 + 0.001) /2) ~= 13. Not (10 + 30) / 2 = 20. On actual realworld data the average quality between the naive method and the proper can differ more than 10 Phred units. That is an overestimation of the quality by a factor of 10! . In the file I investigated, fastp reports the last cycles to have on average quality 34, while analysing it with a correct algorithm yields 22. The latter value is closer to 1 error per 100 which seems much more realistic than the less than 1 error per 1000 quality that fastp reports.

sentence: deduplication with UMI; I could not find description about how deduplication is done for fastq with UMI. I found "fastp considers one read as duplicated only if its all base pairs are identical as another one." Is it the same for fastq with UMI? Thanks!
author: OpenGene

sentence: PhiX contamination; Hi! . I want to know if FastP have the possibility of remove Phix remnant sequences in reads of samples. . I know that the Illumina instrument is able to remove some of them, but in my experiencie, most of the fragments remain inserted in the sequences of interest. . Someone can help me or someone knows that this issue could be solved soon by the authors? . Thank you!!!
